content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												Dead Space 2 is arguably one of the best action horror games that any lover of horror genre games should make sure to  experience firsthand. The RPG elements mixed in with the TPS storytelling mesh perfectly with one another to bring an unforgettable sequel akin to its equally great predecessor. That being said, the two games are both good but in different ways: The first Dead Space was more of a creepy horror game with action being its sidekick, while Dead Space 2 is more of a sci-fi shooter with some creepy aspects to it; there was an inverse, but nothing was inherently lost from the overall gameplay. However, your own opinion may vary depending upon your susceptibility to being scared, and this game certainly does not disappoint in that department--The game puts you straight into the shocking, fast-paced, frightening action right from the beginning. Dead Space 2 also polishes up a few facets from the last game such as a better zero-g flight system and controls, more weapons, and more enemies in order to bring a more expansive, smooth gameplay to the player. Of course, there are still a few funny glitches such as the physics and movements of the many cadavers scattered throughout each chapter; it is almost like gmod decided to visit space in a sense. Also, gameplay is very similar to the first game (as you should expect): smash and dismember everything in your path or be dismembered and eviscerated yourself. Simple survival rules to say the least by Darwinian Standards. I definitely recommend picking up this game if you liked the first Dead Space. I do not even have to go through the five stages of grief after finishing this game to come to the conclusion that Dead Space 2 easily deserves a 9/10. So keep your "eye out" for when it goes on sale in the Steam Store. The only thing I have a problem with is the fact that Dead Space 3 has yet to be released on Steam...so pick it up on console or get yourself an Origin Account in the meanwhile until that fateful day comes if you cannot wait after finishing Dead Space 2.

A Screenshot of Dead Space 2
By: Jaeger




So This Game Has many new and improved features from its predeseccor such as many new suits, new wepaons, new suit abilities and new enemies to name a few. In my honest opinion, his Game takes some steps away from the Bare Horror Genre and mixes it with a bit of mass effect's Special effects. (Both made by EA, hmmmm.) its quite an action packed ride albeit a very short one! There are moments in this game where it gets very fast paced, there are other moments where its very Gory and Shocklingly Tense (In true Dead Space Style). After all, Improvements are the Main things you want to hear after you hear the Word-Sequel. So without Further ado, heres the Good and Bad, simplified..Pros:+the Story is Short, for casual gamers this is Good News! (Approx 10-12 hours on Normal)+Simplified Mechanics means that Tutorials take less time! yay.Graphics feel smoother than DS1 and much more mellow colours/themes in levels.+The Battle isnt just on the sprawl, it also spans a unique conflict in Isaac's Mind, His Mental Health is Greatly affected from the events of the previous game (No Spoilers here) and any chance of "recovery" is......Absolutely Obliterated.+Plot (although short) is interesting and keeps you interested in the developments and futures for many of the characters.+So many Upgrades to Choose from (Suits, health, air, armour, ammo and the tough but rewarding "pearl" that is the Work-Bench.+So many Weapon Variations too! There are 11 Main guns in the Game but each have about 3 different variations for elemental effects or special features that belong with a special suit. Lots of work clearly done here.+So many New Enemies! yay, there are specific enemies for dark areas, zero-G, Open Halls and even Plastered on Walls! (Euurgh.)+Voice Acting is Slightly above average, giving Isaac a voice was a risky decision but EA pulled it off alright in the end i think.+The Atmosphere and Environments! of Course, many new areas are seen in the Story that were only mentioned in the first game. Obviosly the biggest one being a massive Church of Unitology! this really gives a deep insight into the Culture of the Cult members and even some instances of segregation because of it! This kind of detail is rare for a game, especially for a Horror!+Speaking of Environments, you can now fly/jet around in space in some parts. the controls took me a while to learn however.+While this might not be a true down to the roots-horror game, its definietely a Gory Ride. Once again Dead Space lives up to its R18 Rating. One Scene Worth Mentioning is the MANUAL Laser eye surgery segment...DONT Screw up!, 'Nuff Said+Im a Sucker for Hard Difficulties in Horror games, and luckily Dead Space 2 didnt dissappoint: The Impossible Mode from Dead Space 1 has grown into a real man now! Hard-core Gamers can now experience the (Wisely named) Hard-Core mode! The Main feature of this mode is that you now only have 3 Saves to use throughout th whole story, this combined with regular things like OP enemies, low Health and Little to NO Supplies make it a very challenging experience, almost...a Horror Game.


YouTube™ Video: DEAD SPACE 2 executions multiplayer 

			Views: 10,179		



Cons:-Its Too Bloody Short! its a breeze on easy and normal. only on hard or above do you really see the kind of experience it intended! Gathering Supplies Really makes the Game a lot more challenging and takes away from the Constant action-Cutscenes are very Linear and suddenly turn int QTE's when you least expect! (Timing is everything!)-Some Lag/Frame Rate drops that i experienced. (around 2 per playthrough, not too bad)-Theres hardly any Boss Battles in the game! and when there is, they are nowhere close to the unique battles that DS1 had!-Because its a very short game, the time to understand Isaac's "persona" and motivations is drastically reduced. Action>"Mind Battle" with Nicole>Action>Plot>Cutscene>Boss>Action>Repeat. Thats basically a cycle of events really.-An Abundance of Ammo is great! but DS2 has the opposite.. (in the harder modes this is changed obviously.) This doesnt help the Horror Name of DS2 and really changes it into an Action-Packed one instead. Which is True! For Some people this is good, for others its bad. But the Atmosphere overall doesnt Compare with the Confines of the Ishimura or Tight Spaces in Zero-G from the First Game. Instead, it seems like a Rushed Plot which has good directions for the story but is cut short after the Final Boss (Great Boss though) and isnt explained Clearly. Which is exactly what the Third game is for, wow!! Bloody EA...Final Thoughts:I think this game makes many improvments in common areas, but NOT Atmosphere and the Mysteriousness and Scariness that it held deep inside the Ishimura! Story is standard really, which sets itself up for a third game very well. Not as much Backstory as the First game. Which is strange because there is a 3 Year Gap inbetween 1 and 2! BUT Since im such a fan, here is the Order of the DS Series! (To Read, Play and watch!):Martyr (Book) Dead Space (Graphic Novel)Downfall (Animated Film)Extraction (Wii Game)First GameSalvage (Graphic Novel)Aftermath (Graphic Novel)Dead Space (Mobile Game)Ignition (Xbox Minigame)Second GameThird/Final Game + the DLC  Hope that was Helpful.Anyway I rate this game a 7.5/10!An interesting sequel with a heavy Focus on Isaac's Mind and Unitology! as well as many minor improvements..http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=582353606Hope you liked this Review for the last Dead Space game on steam! ;( Leave a Comment with any questions below, as usual :D-Kyle

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												Dead Space 2 is a gigantic, flying leap over Dead Space 1 in many ways.Pros:  Dozens of gameplay refinements from Dead Space 1: Issac moves much easier and aims much faster, with animations getting almost complete overhaul ( for example, Issac's badass backhand is now replaced with a much faster punch, and his stomp comes out way faster and is much easier to spam). You can now pick up Necromorph blades or rods and shoot them into enemies, allowing you to deal with individual foes much easier and save ammo. New enemy types keep combat fresh, like introducing the long-range debuffing Puker or the agile Stalker to keep the player on their toes. New weapons make for a much more interesting combat experience, with interesting ideas like the Javelin Gun or the Detonator alongside classics like the Plasma Cutter, Line Gun and Pulse Rifle.  Beautiful graphics and sound: The game, while showing it's currently five year old age in a hell of a lot of places (like ♥♥♥♥♥♥ DRM, and long distance objects looking like crap) has some absolutely beautiful locations- standouts include the Government Sector, the Unitologist Church/Residence and more. Lighting effects are at their prime here, with detailed, colourful mood lighting that adds to the setpieces: having the only light be Issac's helmet glow is an effect that REALLY should have been used more often as it simply looks beautiful.  Good Story: Having Issac be voiced is a contentious decision, but I think it works. It helps that his voice acting is pretty good, and the story is much more engaging with him being voiced. Issac being mute in the last game was something I disliked, so it's nice to see him express himself here. The story is much more personal and cinematic this time around, and it has a good resolution at the end. Replayability: Don't let my 7-ish hours ingame fool you- i've beaten DSII at least 4 times- 3 on PS3 and once on PC and  it's still a blast! The myriad of weapons, unique combat encounters and wide tools almost demand multiple playthroughs, and the new game plus of this game is on the same tier of Resident Evil 4- just as fun as the first time through, though way easier. My total time with this game has been at least 23 hours total across all the playthroughs, and i've only spent about $20 on this game across buying it twice. It's got a lot of content.Cons:Too much action: The unfortunate side of things is that DSII is rarely scary. While DSI wasn't too scary either, it at least tried. DSII is full on action from start to finish, like Alien to Aliens. However, the truly spooky parts, like the first encounter with the stalkers in the church or the appearance of an old pal from DSI towards the end of the game are very memorable. It's a shame that the relentless action kinda ruins the atmosphere, because the creepy atmosphere in many locations can make your skin crawl. Horrible Install: Despite running very well, the setup process for this game can be a real pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ Seriously, it took me at least half an hour to get it working, and that's with no issues on my end.Overall: An excellent action horror experience- by cutting off the fluff and refining the core of Dead Space combat, a truly great game was made. A classic everyone should try.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												Dead Space 2 is in some ways a big improvement over it's predecessor. - The controls in DS2 are much more fluid and reactive. This was one of the biggest downfalls of the original. Good job.- Isaac actually talks in DS2 so you get a sense of his personality instead of playing a mute character. Good job.- Removed the overly obnoxious heavy breathing of the no-oxygen areas, and cleaned up the zero-gravity areas to be more fun and easier to control. Good job.Overall though, the first DS offered a stronger atmosphere and sense of helplessness than DS2, which surprised me a bit. Also the way the chapters are done in DS2 didn't seem to make much sense or have a rhyme or reason. For example, you could just crawl out of a vent (with nothing major happening to advance the story) and you just randomly entered a new champter. How does crawling out of a vent trigger a new chapter? It wasn't really a big deal and didn't effect the game, but it made the game feel like it was lacking direction.I felt like DS2 suffered greatly from poor character development. DS1 actually had decent character development and I had a pretty good sense of their personalities. DS2 took a step back from that.The gameplay is nearly identical to the first one with the addition of a few new items you can use kinesis on for combat. I was hoping for some really cool boss battles, but I was disappointed once again (I feel like EA could be so creative with these monsters that they could make some insanely cool boss fights. How did this not happen?). In some ways DS2 was better than DS1, but in other ways it took a step back. While the game is somewhat fun and I recommend it, I don't think it is the strongest franchise. DS2 takes about 12-15 hours to complete. 7.5/10Please upvote this review if you found it useful :)

content:
Posted: September 27, 2013
												Short version: An improvement on the original in almost every way, tight and adrenaline fueled combat, one of the only video game gun upgrade systems that seems both justified and interesting and generally pretty fun to play. Just don't expect to be scared or to give a single♥♥♥♥♥♥about any of the characters. 8/10. If you can get it on sale for $10 or less I'd say it's a must buy.I bought this on sale for $5 and generally speaking I'd say I would've payed more. The gameplay is loads of fun and combat can be very, very hectic, in a good way. The zero gravity sections from the first game have been massively improved and are now actually fun to do and what I would generously call "puzzles" are few and far between which is good in a game like this. The graphics are very good and most of the settings you play through look gorgeous. On a related note the Dead Space series' one innovation, the completely menu diagetic interface, returns and is as neat a novelty as ever. There are quite a few action setpieces that, while maybe not memorable, are certainly very impressive and a blast to play through, especially since many of them will take a new player completely by surprise. The only downside to the game is it's pretentions to scaryness. The original Dead Space could almost manage to be scary with its constant dark hallways and feelings of isolation but Dead Space 2 just seems to be trying far, far too hard. The soundtrack loses it's damn mind everytime an enemy spawns, ruining any kind of surprise, and refuses to die down until the very last enemy dies, instantly alerting the player to the fact that there's nothing more to worry about. The game relies almost entirely on jump scares, the vast majority of which will be spotted long beforehand by even the most remotely savvy of players and the few that aren't at all telegraphed will probably have more players laughing than jumping (An alarm clock jumpscare, really?). The game also tries desperately to up the ante of the first game's monsters with, get this, child enemies and even BABY enemies both of which come across as more humerous than terrifying. The first 3-4 hours of gameplay also has an almost pathological tendency to introduce characters only to see them murdered horibbly within a matter of minutes (or in several cases, seconds) which means that most players will never start to care about the actually important characters because they'll be assuming a quick-but-painful death in their near future. So while the game is great fun and certainly worth it's price, don't expect a truly scary experience unless you're a twitchy coward. Oh and there's multiplayer too but I never tried it because honestly who gives a♥♥♥♥♥♥-Also, it's important to note that this steam release apparently comes with all the various weapon and armor packs free of charge, all of which can be purchased in-game at the very first store you come across at an unbelievable price of 0 dollars. I recommend against using any of them on your first playthrough because they break game balance over their knee and ruin what little tension the game managed.

												Dead Space 2 is one of my favorite games, right below the first Dead Space.Pros-Great Story-Isaac is no longer an intern for other characters.-More Necromorphs!-Zero-G areas are awesome. (No more jumping from place to place, instead you have boosters.)-Wide selection of suits and weapons, with great upgrades.-Controls are better that the first game.-Interesting Characters.-Action sequences are great and don't take away from the horror (LOOKING AT YOU DEAD SPACE 3!)-Graphics look great even in 2016/2017-Isaac is no longer a silent protagonist, and isn't annoying (for the most part.).-Framerate is smooth/doesn't drop very much. -Includes armor and weapon DLC packs.Cons-Jump scares lose the scare factor as you evolve into the terminator in space.-Lots of console exclusive DLC-Sometimes throws hordes of necromorphs at you, unlike its predecessor.All considered, 9.9/10.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2013
												Despite some technical issues with this slightly questionable Steam port - including a shop chock-full of "unlocked" goodies which would render the game impossibly easy, were you to indulge in them - this is yet another top-rate "survival horror" game set among the stars.     Like most horror game sequels it "opens up" the setting to something far more epic than a mere Haunted House romp, but whether this is a good or bad thing is of course up to individual tastes.  A part of me still votes in favour of the "purity" of the somewhat narrower setting of the earlier game, but if they HAD to mess all that up with a sequel, you really couldn't have asked for a better job.     Looking forward to the third one, though the question is slowly arising:  How many more Dead Spaces can they do before the premise becomes a tad exhausted?  Only time will tell...Verdict: 9/10.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												Having never played any Deadspace game, it felt reminiscent of Half-life and the Alien film smashed together. The atmosphere and environment art was stellar, filled with detail, dynamic lighting and smoke effects. It's not too scary or predictable, though there are some jump scares.  Most of the tension comes from the spooky music, the way the enemies move, and how danger suddenly spawns or flanks you. There's also some great gore scenes. The combat was very satisfying, and it was unique to focus on dismembering limbs and stomping on stuff instead of doign flat contact damage.  Overall, it is a very well put together game.The parts I didn't like were that enemies pop up unrealistically close to you, and is often what's scary - that something loud and dangerous is suddenly right next to you.  The weapon system was a little overwhelming because of all the options. You ride in upwards of 100 elevators and manual saving felt tedious as the game went on. Some of the story was nonsensical - worthy of being made fun of.  There's some gravity gun-esque gameplay that felt tired and out of place, and sometimes you have to mash a button to get away from an enemy.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												Like it's predecessor, Dead Space 2 takes place in a horror survival scenario where Isaac Clarke, our protagonist, must combat multitudes of enemies using his weapons, the surrounding environment, and even the sharp appendages of defeated enemies to survive. Unlike in the predecessor, Isaac Clarke (whom had rarely if not ever spoke in Dead Space 1) was now fleshed out and given a personality (and an enjoyable one at best). The gore is still everywhere in this game and it lives up to Dead Space 1. The game has about 10-12 hours of gameplay with replayability in it's NewGame+ and Hardcore mode, where you only get three saves and barely enough health and ammo to live. Give this game a go if you have a bit of extra money in your wallet, you won't be disapointed.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
												It's safe to assume at this point in my life that I'm not a big fan of survival horror games considering that, for example, I've only played one of the many Resident Evil games out there, the fith one, considered by many the less scarier in the series. I think the main reason is that I'm easily scared and playing this kind of games for me is like being tortured, my heart is always beating at 150% and I'm always ready to jump off my chair.Everything changed after Dead Space. I've always been a sci-fi fan and when I heard back in 2008 that a sci-fi game, located in space and full of alien like monsters then I didn't care anymore about my heart....or my chair. The fear never disapeared, but the game..oh boy..was so enjoyable. Now the sequel, Dead Space 2. I remember that I read some years ago an article stating that Dead Space 2 was to Dead Space as Aliens was to Alien, nothing better to describe it. In Dead Space you are in a spaceship, a very large one indeed but still a spaceship, in Dead Space 2 the scale is much bigger and the amount of monsters and scary moments are increased in the same proportion. Even today, being a 2011 game with somewhat outdated graphics, this like the first one are 2 of the best survival horror titles out there, real jewels.Dead Space 3 was good, for some reasons, not incredible like the first two but either way I hope to see sooner rather than later a new Dead Space title.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												First of all the actual game is awesome! It's a really great story that mixes strange religious cultism with horror, and leaves enough of the backround ambiguous to make it mysterious. The game also runs silky smooth on PC, and is a far better port than the original was. The link in with EA has been HIGHLY exaggerated also. Literally all you have to do is sign into an EA account, which many people probably have if they own a console, or have ever used Origin. It's really not as big a deal as everyone says.The two major flaws however are as follows: 1) You can only install this game a certain number of times so be carfeful not to uninstall unless you're finished with the game. It wasn't a huge problem for me as I got it on sale and only planned to do a quick run through, but for people who like to, you know, KEEP WHAT THEY FREAKING PAID FOR, or are just struggling with HDD space it may be a problem.2) The second flaw is kind of mind boggling. They must have included all the DLC for free with the game, because when you hit the very first store in the game you get access to all of the weapons and armour in the game straight away. Again this wasn't a big deal for me as I had already played this game on console and this basically gave me a free NG+ to run through the campaign, but I can see this seriously♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥some people off, especially new players.All in all the game is great, and if you have no problem with the gripes i've mentioned then you may as well get it. However maybe if you've never played it before, buy it from origin as the DLC may not be included there, and you might get the full normal experience.Game - 9/10This Version  - 7/10

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Dear Dead Space™ 2 review reader,The Dead Space™ 2  game will be forever imbedded into my brain. No regrets buying it with the combo game pack (along with Dead Space™ ) FOR PC.I had the intention of playing it with the upgraded plasma cutter from Dead Space™ 1, however, am still clueless if DS2 managed to detect and include that information into the in-game store. Nevertheless, I started the game in anticipation with the memories of my experience with DS1; on Zealot mode. No less. No necromorph is going to come up and shake my hand in any difficulty, so what the heck, right?As a graphic art enthusiast, the fluent user interface of the menu/ingame, colour scheme, stunning artwork on buildings and scenery, character a.i. and attention to detail (especially object animation and interaction) was the cream of the crop for me. From the hours spent on developing the game, you'd  know  that they loved creating it as much as you will love playing it.As usual, the game starts off with an action-packed bounded sequence which really gets the blood flowing. If you had had a break from DS1 after a while... this will just jolt you back into "reality". Absolutely love the way developers give you a moment of silence now and then with the chills going down your spine while you raid and explore the beautiful Titan Station. Where there are necromorphs... you're definitely to be on the edge of the seat the whole time... forgetting whether you have  collected that stasis pack at the corner or checked that inconspicious pile of janitorial equipment at the medical deck of the  USG Ishimura . The storyline is particularly intriguing and at times, marvelling with unexpected twists.This game is action-packed (sometimes crazy overly), horrifying and gruelling at times. It ends in the most  cheapest bossfight imaginable... but absolutely DOABLE . Remember, in any Dead Space game, never... ever.... give up.. So without further ado• What I totally dig:  - The Graphics (Character, Suits, Scenery, Buildings, etc)  - The Challenges (Necromorphs, Puzzles, Quick-time Events)  - The Gear and Guns (Exsisting Guns and Suits in-game as well as the Extra Content Gear instore)  - The Unexpected Surprises (Diamond Semiconductors, Jump attacks)  - Extended Breadcrumb Locator menu (Loved it, includes nearest Save Station, Bench & Store)  - The Experience (In-game sound, atmosphere, Zero-G baby!)• What I did not quite get:  - The most obvious glitch in-game which happens for me, was that when you press the Tab Key while holding the Aim button (right mouse button), Isaac will be in a constant state of aiming even though you press everything else including shoot. This brings other interactive issues, which you can't do while aiming. Do Not Save the game in this state.The only way, I found out to undo this glitch, is to restart DS2 application and reload a previous save game. The glitch also happens at the medical deck where a triggered cutscene happens. So if you were aiming, again.. restart DS2 Application and load last saved game. This glitch also happens in DS1.  - The last boss battle,  was cheap. Many people had suggested to use the Contact beam or Detonator for "easy"  boss defeat, but then again, why have all those other awesome guns? Experiencing it in Zealot mode, it was frustrating... 25 tries, or more. but I was resolute in getting the job done with my souped up Javelin, Line gun and Pulse Rifle for the "other" challenge. It was still a success, just that because of timing or luck... probably both. Would have preferred a better boss fight. • Personal Tips while Playing Dead Space™ 2:  -   Always be inquisitive.  This can trigger special cutscenes or find yourself that item that gives you the extra edge.  -   Keep calm.  Very often, you'd feel yourself freeze up from the fright. Remember, Isaac is equiped with a stasis module. So, if things get too intense, mesh that C key and dodge the hell out of there!  -   "Run, Isaac, Run!"  Keep moving! Avoid any proximity from necromorphs or hazards. A hit caused by a necromorph can slow you down intensively and waste those precious seconds from regaining control of the character. This in turn will cause swarming. In Zealot mode, first few times being hit will be OHKs (One Hit Kills).  -   Gun Hard-on.  The weapons in the game are amazing and it is always a shame to not try out any of them, if not all of them. Let go and try to have some quality time with the others. It will be worth the high.  -   Watercooler discussion.  Take a break once in a while. The game gets extremely addictive at some points and frustrating at other points. Having fresh sessions per chapter helps and makes it enjoyable rather than repetitive.Hope this review has been helpful. Have a great time playing Dead Space™ 2 and Good Luck!DS2 Gamer,sushibar82©Zealot ModeMarch 2014

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												I suppose the obvious thing to say is that if you liked the original Dead Space then you will enjoy the sequel. There are a couple of differences in the gameplay. Where in the original, you were wandering around a spaceship and could "revisit" certain areas by using the map, so if you needed ammo, you pulled up the map and found the nearest store (or bench or whatever you needed) In the sequel you just head on forward to the next save point in the style of a more traditional arcade shooter, so the game does lose something there.What the game does really well is to make you feel like a badass with a gun, fighting, shooting and chopping off limbs of various aliens is very satisfying indeed, sadly the progression of the game itself lets the whole thing down. You basically head from one point to the next only to find out that you need to fix/repair/switch on something... and when you have done that, you head off to the next thing that will need to be fixed/repaired/switched on before you can continue on your quest. At around 12-15 hours, the game surprisingly starts to wear out it's welcome at around the 10 hour mark, as it begins to feel like the story is stretched out unnecessarily to make the game just that little bit longer. Just when you think you are done, you have to find yet another switch, or head outside and switch more things on. Luckily, the shooting mechanics are great as are the graphics and sound, so that helps make the experience much more enjoyable.So like I said in the first line, if you enjoyed Dead Space, there is no reason you won't like more of the same. I did!

content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
Dead Space 2 is a pinnacle of horror meets space experiences.Short answer:  You must have it I've now played Dead Space 2 twice, once on console and once again here and it felt just as breathtaking as when I first popped the disc into my 360 a few years ago. A timeless experience that will have you staring wideeyed and open mouthed. It may be the first time you curse at the necromorphs on the screen along with Isaac as you fight your way through 15 chapters.What's changed since Dead Space 1?Better controls.More details graphics.More weapons, and improvements on current ones.A boatload of amazing cutscenes you won't want to miss.A very flushed out story that explains more about the Marker, Earthgov, and the Unitologists.The only complaint, if it's even a complaint, is I wasn't as afraid. But this is the second game, I know where to look and what to expect. If you're looking for fear, you're going to get excitement and thrill. Perhaps this is a fear I'm accustomed to, I don't know. It didn't hinder my experience, but I did walk in having some expectation of fear, but I was given the best roller coaster, toddler stomping, baby blasting, necromorph head punching time of my life.

												This game is great! It takes place shortly after the events of DS1 and Isaac still can't catch a break. Overrall, Dead Space 2 was a great continuation to the first game. Someday when I get the courage I know I will play Dead Space 3.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Dead Space 2 is set three years after the events of the first Dead Space game. The game follows protagonist Isaac Clarke's fight against a new Necromorph outbreak on the Sprawl, a space station above Saturn's largest moon, Titan.The game incorporates many aspects of the original Dead Space game that made it such a classic, as a result some may consider the game Dead Space 1.5 rather than Dead Space 2. However, this is not a bad thing. The original game was great and as such, Dead Space 2 fills the large shoes of its predecessor whole and completely. As for the plot, I found it engaging which allowed me to connect with Isaac Clarke and his perilous quest. The gameplay was a smooth and enjoyable experience. In addition, Dead Space 2 was successful in creating a world that left you feeling alone and just one step behind the atrocities of the Necromorph outbreak. The subtle rumblings of a necromorph above you or the eerier silence when entering a new room provided just enough tension to make you jump out your seat when a necromorph jumps out at you.If you thoroughly enjoyed the first Dead Space, Dead Space 2 will not disappoint.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												After waking from a coma on a massive space city known as "The Sprawl", the lone survivor of a horrific alien infestation finds himself confronting a catastrophic new nightmare. He must kick every Necromorph's teeth out to find a way out, while also getting hunted by his dead, but hot ex-girlfriend. While fighting the Necromorhps and his ex-girlfriend, he meets Ellie, also a hot lady friend. Now Issac has got a alot of company to entertain him on his journey.Graphics and sound speak for them selfs.The story is above average(7,5/10) for a horror game, don't walk in here and expect to see some Telltale's storytelling.The enviorment feels like it is ripped from a horror film. From claustrophobic corridors to huge warehouses filled with alot of creates that block your view. You don't know, there can be a Necromorph on every damn corner.The gameplay is where this game shines. Each Necromorph has got it's weaknesses, you can even remove the limbs from them and shoot back at them. There are mini-games, zero gravity parts, great puzzles and like 50 ways in which Issac can die. The game offers great customize abillity, you can choose weapons that best fit your play style and then upgrade them. This game has atleast 8 hours of gameplay and a huge replay abillity, as it's impossible to upgrade everything in a single playthrough and there is also difficulty settings. The controls on PC are perfect.The only dissapointing part is the multiplayer. It falls flat and doesn't offer anything new. For all I care they could've just removed it.9.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												Simply amazing. Let me put it at that. One problem with the first game that I didn't like was the fact that Issac never actually talked. But in this one, him talking adds so much more character development and plot potential, which Viscreal used to the fullest extent. The horror is right on with this expecially with your first playthrough with no idea what's around the corner. Tons of great jump scares and "WTF what is that!?" moments. Lots of different necromorphs to scare the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you. Just the right difficulty. Nothing too extreme. Despite it's linear progression, it really makes you think about what to do for the best results when you die, which you will if it's your first playthrough. Oh and don't forget about the pure EPICNESS of Issac's quest

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												It's best to list the pros and cons for this sequel:+The game seems to be more action-packed this time. Its creepy atmosphere is still there, but action- and cutscene sequences are far more and better.+Isaac finally speaks! Also, he has a face! Visceral realised it was best to get rid of the Freeman-esque protagonist and give him some personality. +I found the gameplay better - stasis and telekinesis seemed easier to be used and the RIG does not display unnecessary things such as the map. There are some clever new enemy types, as well.- Unfortunately, the sequel is a bit shorter. Make no mistake - your first playthrough takes roughly 8-10 hours to complete, still, I remember its predecessor to be a bit longer.- No DLC. For some reason its DLC titled Severed was never released on PC. It's a short DLC with a couple of chapters that follows the story of another protagonist and events are taking place earlier than those of DS 2.- Unnecessary multiplayer. By the time I purchased it nobody was playing multiplayer any more. No wonder the game's 3rd episode got rid of this mode. It was completely unnecessary.Dead Space 2 is still a very good game. The negative list I included is all related to minor things - overall, this is a superb sequel to a horror game that is best played at night with the headset on. The experience is best with players watching Dead Space Aftermath, an animated feature film that is set just before of events of the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												This game is effectively the same as the first gameplay-wise with a few tweaks. There are a some new weapons and the game rewards those who use stasis in combat, i.e. me. There are also new enemies. Some which are more challenging to deal with as the can projectile vomit acid and liquid nitrogen over 100 meters with stunning accuracy.Design-wise, this game is much more linear. You will feel more like you are stumbling through a bunch of set pieces instead of navigating your way through a ship to achieve a task.One aspect you may find jarring is that Issac now has a voice. It's not that bad in the long run. Although the cutscenes and dialog remain unskippable.All-in-all a good experience. You may find some answers behind the marker and necromorphs, but there is still plenty of mystery left.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												I love this game with one major complaint -It comes with the DLC pre-loaded.Why is this a complaint? Well, from the VERY BEGINNING of the game, you have access to many different weapons (and I think even armor suits) that you normally would not. Not to mention, it's all completely free.Now, this is just me, but personally, I do not like having all this extra crap available to me because it really hurts the whole "resource management" aspect of the game. And the survival horror aspect in general. The game is simply easier with the ability to get all of these different guns for free.At least at one point, there was a means (albeit convoluted) of removing the DLC from the game, but it meant reverting to a previous version of the game with less updates/patches. I think that's just stupid. You should be able to disable the DLC prior to starting a new campaign game.But despite that, this game still gets a "thumbs up" because it's just that good. A great sequel to the first.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												Dead Space 2 is a great horror game and a brilliant sequel to the another great horror game.Set, I believe, three years after the events of the first game, Isaac Clarke wakes up in a psych ward in a hospital in a space station, just as the infection that wreaked havoc on the Ishimura (space ship) from the first game breaks out on this space station. Clarke makes his escape while having hallucinations but is also guided by a stranger. This is where the story really kicks off. Because I'm going to avoid giving away any spoilers, I'm just going to say that the person you hallucinate throughout the game is Nicole, Isaac's former love interest from the first game.The brilliance of the horror elements in this game is that it isn't a jump scare type of game. It's genuinely terrifying because of the extent of damage done to this space station due to a breakout in the disease that transforms the people into these abominations of creatures. The most memorable part is, arguably, when you're in a nursery and you see a woman, still alive, trying to cradle her baby, who has visibly transformed. Well, the baby has a yellow, soft belly and if you've played the first game, you'll remember that the yellow areas are weak points prone to explode. You can probably guess what happens to the woman.The soundtrack is nice but the game really shines when there isn't any music at all. Just the vast void of sound is so profound and the slightest creak will catch you off guard. The sound mixing in this game is done expertly. The graphics are stellar. I mean, I can tell it came out in 2011, but the lighting is so great and the textures on the walls and characters are generally fantastic. All around splendid job on graphics. The level design is done well enough where each chapter has a varied design. I especially loved the zero gravity flying around in space. The vastness of it, and being able to see Saturn in the distance (I'm pretty sure it's Saturn) is just so unique.Anyway, I feel like I've said enough. Really, fantastic game. Highly recommend.9.3/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												This was my first AAA purchase, i bought it years ago on the 360, back when i was a console peasant. This was, is, and always will be a favourite of mine, not too puzzling, dificulty scales well, still quite spooky, and smoth combat that is rarely interupted, but makes great use of hitboxes. Ragdoll physics and gib physics cobine almost seamlessly, along with excellent responsiveness to one's intended target. AKA you shoot leg, leg gets cut off where you shot it and ragdolls instantly. This game may also have inspired the, dare i mention it, death fetish tomb raider, better known as tomb raider 2013 however. Language, though not censored, is nowhere near oppressive and is taken in great moderation without sparing the story of emotion. gore, well, i mean if you're playing a zombie horror game but not wanting to see any gore you must be doing it wrong. on the topic of zombie horror, however, DS2 manages to capture the classic feeling of fear that comes with the collapse of society due to an outbreak, but also manages to make the zombies themselves terrifying and wastes no time plunging the player into a high-octane hook showcasing some of the creatures while instilling the initial fear into the player. Tutorial is simple and unobtrusive, albeit drawn out just a bit long (if you consider the first store the end of the tutorial) but does it's job better than most, if not all AAA titles these days, teaching the player how to use the more tactical and less practical skills to ensure that they can learn how to combine them with gunplay and running for your life for an effective strategy later in the game.overall, 8.75/10PC port needs a little bit of bug fixing after all these years and the multiplayer felt like an ever so slightly poorly executed version of L4D2, at least on the 360.-EDIT-the minimum system requirements are way above what you will need to play, i managed a solid 40 FPS average on a 1.7 ghz processor, far less than their suggested 2.8

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												Were you bored of the first game? Felt it didn't flow? Isaac felt a bit robotic and unbelievable? Yeah that's what I thought Dead Space 2 was going to be like.BUT NO.Take the game and put in into a BLENDER OF AWESOME and out comes Dead Space 2! The weapons are better, Isaac can actually talk like a human, the enemies are diverse and their jump scares are more tactful and less repetitive. The zero gravity ability is made 10x better with the ability to manuvoure around in a 3 dimensional plane rather than just jumping from surface to surface...AND THE APPLICATIONS ARE AMAZING. YOU FEEL LIKE IRON MAN!!!!I just couldn't get enough of this game and I was glued to the screen the entire time. Totally blows Dead Space 1 out of the water and some levels felt like Bioshock while others felt like the Scarecrow levels from Batman. Oh my god what will Dead Space 3 bring? WORTH PLAYING!!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Dead Space 2 is set three years after the events of the first Dead Space game. The game follows protagonist Isaac Clarke's fight against a new Necromorph outbreak on the Sprawl, a space station above Saturn's largest moon, Titan.The game incorporates many aspects of the original Dead Space game that made it such a classic, as a result some may consider the game Dead Space 1.5 rather than Dead Space 2. However, this is not a bad thing. The original game was great and as such, Dead Space 2 fills the large shoes of its predecessor whole and completely. As for the plot, I found it engaging which allowed me to connect with Isaac Clarke and his perilous quest. The gameplay was a smooth and enjoyable experience. In addition, Dead Space 2 was successful in creating a world that left you feeling alone and just one step behind the atrocities of the Necromorph outbreak. The subtle rumblings of a necromorph above you or the eerier silence when entering a new room provided just enough tension to make you jump out your seat when a necromorph jumps out at you.If you thoroughly enjoyed the first Dead Space, Dead Space 2 will not disappoint.

												Ahhh, the Dead Space series.  I decided to knock out the 1st two of the series in anticipation to the announcement of the 3rd.  Dead Space 2 was a GREAT game!  Very fun and worth it's asking price too.  Everything that slowed down the 1st game was fixed in this one.  Better controls, limited to no back tracking at all and better animations.  High production value and it shows.  I do believe that Dead Space 1 was the better experience, but Dead Space 2 was the better game.No more the silent protaganist as Isaac Clarke now speaks and while I was initially turned off by this it's actually not all that bad.  Additionally, now there's Multiplayer!  Played Left 4 Dead multiplayer?  Then you've play DSMP.  Game on!

content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												Notice the glaring differences between the cover of this game and the prequel. The first game shows a severed arm drifting into the emptiness. It illustrates the dangerous and desolate nature of space. The second game takes a more 'gamey' approach showing the player in a manly helmet. This should give you a rough idea on how they differ. What follows is a continued comparative analysis because why the hell not?! One of the biggest issues with the first game was the oversupply of ammo. It was nothing but a hindrance to setting that despondent mood that I was yearning for. This game on Zealot (hardest difficulty available on first run through) does a better job, usually forcing you to micromanage and conserve your ammo by using other methods of necromorph destruction. The lighting is top notch and the sound is great, especially in zero gravity! One would think these improvements would bump them scary vibes up to 11! Well have they? You've left behind the oppressive, flesh smeared corridors of the first game and been dropped into a more open, relatable environment. If you're wondering if the spritely decor of this game diminishes the levels of suspense driven apprehension you'd be right. Ooo did a toy just ominously roll into view in the next room? Sorry I was too busy investigating this rainbow for missing colours. Rarely did I have a lapse in composure. Only the black as pitch office/cafeteria and a slice off Chapter 10 offered enough atmosphere for me to take a vigilant approach. Furthermore the jumpscares aren't as plentiful as the first game. Less jump scares means better quality scares you say? Nah the lack of originality renders most of them as predictable as the discussion topics of a feminazi night out. Enough lollygagging about atmoscares!.. or jumpsphere! They introduced some new enemies in this game. From children swarming you in groups like you're the surrogate mother of mankind to enemies looking like a rejected pokemon, stampeding at you head first trying to sell the notion that living on one TM is effective. They sold it alright. While I admire Headbutt in the pokemon world it's the utmost annoyance in this game. Sitting in a corner waiting for the next one to charge is boring. Being aggressive can easily lead to your death as they'll usually one shot you on Zealot. Maybe I'm just bad but ♥♥♥♥ those things! If they managed not to give you an one way express pass to a funeral home, it's likely you banged them up with your super mega awesome range of weapons of which were improved from the first game. 5 or 6 weapons that I found were satisfyingly impactful as opposed to the mere 3 in the first game. Oh and kinesis impalement exists. What's not to love there?Love doesn't end there though. Once you finish the game you can play through it again in NG+ or restart naked with only 3 saves at your disposal. It's a nifty feature and more games should have it. Now the love ends. Many a time I leaped into vents like a highly trained rat but crawled through them like a centipede with my legs tied together. These vents are used to transition between some levels but to me it smells of a cop out by the level designers. Oh and who do I have to line gun in the face for including disappearing corpses? I earned that loot ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥it.In Dead Space the desolate ship was a vehicle used to portray the eminence of atmosphere while the sequel threw you into a more approachable world. Ergo as a fear inducing chamber in pixel form it pales in comparison to the first but simply as a video game it's a step up from its predecessor and one of the most solid ones out there.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												I bought the PS3 edition a year or two before purchasing the PC ported game. After worrying for hours how it would play, smoothly or choppy, on my ASuS laptop...The game worked beautifully and dare I say even faster on here. The game has a lovely story as always, and after quitting the PS3 edition because of hatred to the controller gameplay, I am happy to say I will perservere and finally beat this god damn game. Here's the pros and cons:PROS:    - Interesting Story           Isaac Clarke has been admitted to a psychiactrics ward where he must escape. But beyond there, it's a terrifying        nightmare that pushes your tolerance to the ultimate limits.   - Great Graphics          Even for the worst computers, the graphics really stand out and work well for the game. The characters, being the most important in terms of detail, are stunning to say the least.   - Weapons          Every survival game needs weapons. Well, except for Outlast™ and a few select others. Anywho, the weapons really stand out and are unique. They a small part consists of makeshift weapons, such as a surgical lazer and fire extinquisher. the rest are things like pulse rifles and spear guns, which are really cool as well.   - Save, Shop, and Store Stations          This game would be horrifically hard without the features you find repeating in the areas of your journey. These are of course the save station, the item shop, the bench, and the numerous stasis chargers you find. The save station is pretty self explanitory, being where you can save your game. The item shop is where you can store items, buy items, and sell items. It's really needed for a game of this stature. The bench is useful too, giving you a place to upgrade armor and weapons, kinda like the enchanting table from Minecraft™.CONS:   - Glitches             Every game has glitches, it's unavoidable. Even then, this goes in the list. I haven't run into many, but a few have been tht I found enemies stuck in walls and scenery, and falling through elevators happened on one rare occasion. Even then, it doesn't break immersion and this isn't that bad. It's actually kinda.. funny.   - Multiplayer             I know whatcha thinking; "Dood. How cud multiplayar b bad!?". Well, it's not the basic idea, the gameplay, or the entire thing itself. It's the lack of people. If you want to buy this game, don't do it for the sake of multiplayer. It's not going to work if you randomly match, and for that you should get a console release. But if you REALLY wanna play multiplayer, get a large group of friends (4-8) and then you're set.   I'll update this as I continue playing. Right now, the rating it a 8/10.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												This game is really fun! You wake up in a mental hospital, because you keep having visions of hot babes, and they mess up your concentration. Suddenly the hospital is under attack by aliens, who have been hunting you for 11 years after you gambled with them and lost, but the fee you had to pay was too much so you made a break for it. Well, they found you after 11 years. You pick up a gun, which looks badass, and you have no idea how to use but it looks badass as I said, so you keep it, and don this EPIC space suit that attracts all the female aliens, but you're too good for them so you have to put them in stasis and break their limbs off. How complicated the life of a space plumber is with the relationships and the gambling and the guns!You escape to a huge spaceship, and take shelter there. You meet some more aliens, and believe me this game doesn't get repetitive, since it's not like you shoot aliens throught the game or anything, I mean EA are smarter than that. You meet a woman, with one eye, who claims she can cure you from your hot babe visions. Suddenly, Isaac Clarke (that's you) goes from being a space plumber who always shows his crack while fixing the portal potties to a ladies man and alien hunter (just like how Abraham Lincoln became a Vampire Hunter). The jump scares don't get repetitive and this game is SUPER scary that you will probably get a heart attack while playing it. I highly recommend this game to people who love the ladies and shooting aliens. I DON'T recommend this to people who enjoy shooting aliens over and over again, because that is NOT what you do in this game.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2012
												The Dead Space series is one that I have an ambivalent relationship with. On one hand, it is a made that is solid both in its mechanics and presentation. On the other, there is not much that is original or substantial about the experience. While presenting itself as a survival-horror experience, a feeling of helplessness and danger is all but removed by the games lack of dynamism. Enemies try very hard to kill you at every turn with little reprieve, and while the survival aspect is bolstered by the scarcity of ammunition and supplies, the journey becomes frustrating and stressful much more than it does scary as there is very little reward presented when overcoming challenges.The graphics are gorgeous and characters are well acted and animated, especially Elly, whose who owes her voice and appearance to Sonita Henry of Star Trek fame. But even these nice touches do little to redeem the derivative, vapid story and tedious gameplay.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Isaac hunts againThe controls for the PC version of DS1 were awful. The good news is that these have been improved in DEAD SPACE 2 and are no longer the issue they were in the original. (There are still some problems with camera angles when boxed into a corner but these are an irritation rather than a deal breaker.) DS2 also handles zero gravity in a far more intuitive, and enjoyable way, with none of the crazy hopping from one surface to another as in the first game. Now you can move freely, as you would expect. Also improved in DS2 is Isaac’s level of interaction. Now he speaks! This actually improves the experience more than might be expected, as it gives a greater sense that you’re involved in an unfolding story. The graphics are above average quality though not outstanding. The gameplay is improved by the introduction of more varied environments (although this is still very much a corridor shooter), and there are still plenty of tense moments when battling with enemies, some of which will be familiar if you played DS1, and some of which are new. When compared with the original DS2 is basically more of the same but with a number of welcome improvements and enhcncements. On a final note: I found it a little easier than the first, but that might be because of the improved controls and my familiarity with the gameplay second time around. Anyhoo, there’s still plenty of nerve-jangling fun to be had. Recommended, especially if you liked the original.4/5

content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												Great sequal in one of the best contemporary survival horror series. Dead Space 2 has improved graphics, slight but noticeable gameplay improvements that make combat that little bit more fun--yet that little bit less scary to beat but it's a trade-off that still works. The game's environments, sounds, rooms with flickering emergency power, etc., all as scary as the original. The enemies are very similar to those in the original but that is fine because it makes sense with the storyline and Dead Space has some of the most unique enemies in any game of its kind. AI is still great, unpredictable, and therefore quite scary.All in all, this game improves on a lot of what the original already did well. For fans of survival horror, if Dead Space is a must-have, Dead Space 2 is right along there beside it! 9/10.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2013
												If the first Dead Space redefined the survival-horror genre, then it's sequal redefines the redefinition.  Dead Space 2 takes all the aspects that made it's older brother a success (chilling story, excellent gun-play and a stunning atmosphere) and doubles them in quality, while the brand-new and well-balanced multiplayer adds well-deserved replay value in what could have been game of the year.  Even if you're not into the horror genre, you need to check this game out; you won't regret it; you can't regret it!

content:
Posted: September 24, 2016
												In space, no one can hear your dead girlfriend trying to possess you.


YouTube™ Video: 2spoopy - Dead Space 2 (PC) 

			Views: 23		

			In space, no one can hear you slowly lose your mind while being possessed by your dead girlfriend and undead things trying to kill you. ***** Dead Space 2 is copyright Visceral Games, 2011.		

This game is a fantastic followup to the original Dead Space.  While many will call the original Dead Space little more than "Resident Evil 4 in space" (and I'm inclined to agree with them), Dead Space 2 manages to branch out into psychological horror and keep the tension high.  Yeah, there are still jump scares, but the atmosphere overall has been cranked up to 11 and the shootouts are even more frenzied.I don't know how they did it, but they managed to make it work both on the action and the horror front.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2012
												After the frankly pretty poor port of Dead Space with its floaty, imprecise controls and sub par visual presentation, I was hoping that the port of Dead Space 2 would be handled better. And boy it sure was! The controls are precise with Issac moving smoothly and aiming being alot more responsive. Also the visual presentation is fantastic! With the eeire atmosphere of the Sprawl being conveyed brilliantly in conjunction with the stellar audio presentation to make the Sprawl a consistantly engaging setting. There are issues with the game certainly, such as the over-reliance on cheap jump scares rather than building its horror to truely terrify the player. Also the story could have been so much more with Issac barely given a personality other than "Bland everyman" and the human antagonist is barely seen only having 2-3 scenes in the whole game before the final encounter. However! Look past these issues and you'll find a really fun third person shooter with a great atmosphere to boot!

Posted: February 4, 2016
												Not only is this one of the best games I have played, it has one of the best stories to go along with it, with books and short films (of which I have read and seen all), it really stands apart from the crowd because of this.The Game-play is unprecedented for its time and is easily one of the most gripping and intuitive play-styles that have ultimately made me love this series, and with Dead space 2 it builds onto the creepy atmospheres and scary environments.However with the above being amazing it wouldn’t actually be as half good as it is without the music score behind it. It keeps you one edge and sets the mood in the game so perfectly I have freaked out over absolutely nothing when the violins strung a little to hard and made me jump.Personally, I would recommend a controller for this.Game-play 9/10Music score 10/10Story 9.5/10OVERALL 9.5/10 - A game that will be worth your full attention.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Absolutely awesome game. Some claim the horror elements are completely replaced by action, but that is not true. While the third game clearly goes down the action route, this game finds a perfect balance between action, horror, and story. Isaac finally talks! He's now reacting to things, talking to people, connecting to people, and responding to his hallucinations. It gives the game's narrative a much stronger and believable feel this time around. The gameplay mechanics are largely the same, with some new tweaks and additions here and there. Overall a more refined, intense, and emotional journey than the first.

Pros+ Atmosphere+ Game play is excellent. Very satisfying+ Had to be very resourceful and patient. (At least on the Zealot difficulty)+ Good story and voice acting+ Plasma Cutter is BaeCons- The DLC. Let me explain... The Steam version includes all the DLC for the game which is cool but its all overpowered weapons and suits for single player that are literally free from shops in the game from the very start. Personally I didn't use them for the fact it would just ruin the game for me. It was annoying having to navigate through all the DLC items cluttering up the shops through out the game.- CrawlersOverall a great game and one of the best survival horror games I've played. A massive improvement in almost every way over its predecessor (Which was still a really good game). Final Score - ★★★★☆

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												A well-done immersive survival horror game.Be amazed at how quickly time flies with this game. On a three-day weekend, I almost played it all the way through.It's almost a prerequisite to play Dead Space (1) first because many of the tactics that are used in 1 are needed in 2.  You will need to capitalize on some of those same methods.For example, the distribution of ammo from dead enemies is based mainly on the weapons that you have. It's not clear that having many weapons is actually detrimental to your gaming experience. Although the spawning of ammo from dead enemies is not as strict as it was in Dead Space 1, it still applies to a certain degree here.  Try to have a small set of weapons of 3.  Plasma Cutter ( the "pistol" of the game) is a requirement to keep for it's low cost of buying ammo and upgrading.  FYI, this is one of the reasons why Dead Space 3 had changed to "Universal Ammo" that can be used for any weapon. Other than keeping this in mind, you should be fine.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2012
												Horror games nowerdays are very week. Lacking actual fear, aticipation and pure thrills all in one package. Dead Space 2 however will give you all that and more!Gameplay: The gameplay is a solid 3rd person shooter. You have to react fast and learn skills quicly to surive on hard settings. New enemies mean new ways to kill.Story: An intresting a deep storyline that contiues were the last game left of. Whilst not as deep or mystic still delivers a solid storyline.Graphics: Above par and excellently atmospheric feel, with lighting and blood and gore that a epic Horror game should have. Plus an excellent optmised engine. The game used only 30% of my CPU and only one core, amazing to say the graphics are as amazing as they are.So overall, this along with the original Dead Space are instant classics, both for hall of fame and the pioneer of Horror games.I give it a 9.8/10Pro's:- Explores the old ship, very nostagic- Just an Epic gameCon's:- Could use better use of Audio

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
												Dead Space 2 lets you take control of Isaac Clarke again as he tries to survive a space colony on Saturn's biggest moon, Titan. The games brings a lot more to the table this time. A few new weapons, such as a giant spike gun that impales and  electrocutes enemies. Game mechanics have been tuned up. The game runs a lot more smoothly and melee is much more effective. The suit system returns too, but this time each suit has it's own little bonus, like giving you a discount at the store. They even redid the Zero Gravity parts so you have full control over your character. A few new enemies have been added, including an enemy that uses cover then tries to sneak behind you.Overall the game feels like a sequel instead of just a modded add on or DLC. Just make sure as you near the end of the game you are fully upgraded. It has quite the difficulty spike near the end.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2012
												The Dead Space series is one that I have an ambivalent relationship with. On one hand, it is a made that is solid both in its mechanics and presentation. On the other, there is not much that is original or substantial about the experience. While presenting itself as a survival-horror experience, a feeling of helplessness and danger is all but removed by the games lack of dynamism. Enemies try very hard to kill you at every turn with little reprieve, and while the survival aspect is bolstered by the scarcity of ammunition and supplies, the journey becomes frustrating and stressful much more than it does scary as there is very little reward presented when overcoming challenges.The graphics are gorgeous and characters are well acted and animated, especially Elly, whose who owes her voice and appearance to Sonita Henry of Star Trek fame. But even these nice touches do little to redeem the derivative, vapid story and tedious gameplay.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												really good game... The follow up to Dead Space does everything better. It is darker and has a more gritty vibe to it.Gameplay is solid and at times it will make you sweat...If you didn't play the first part then you should before giving this game a go.The story just continues after the first Dead Space,, There is no quite and/or slow beginning, after a brief intro,where you are sitting and talking about past experiences (Dead Space 1) with your shrink things start to go crazy from the beginning.. Stop thinking, start running for your life in the hell called Dead Space 2.You will not get a minute to get a breath because in this part of the Dead Space all hell breaks loose straight away..Graphics are a little better, sound in my opinion the same (good) and the gameplay is awesome..Highly essential videogame series... I'd rate this about a 8,7 out of 10. Get this and start playing...

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
Pros+ Atmosphere+ Game play is excellent. Very satisfying+ Had to be very resourceful and patient. (At least on the Zealot difficulty)+ Good story and voice acting+ Plasma Cutter is BaeCons- The DLC. Let me explain... The Steam version includes all the DLC for the game which is cool but its all overpowered weapons and suits for single player that are literally free from shops in the game from the very start. Personally I didn't use them for the fact it would just ruin the game for me. It was annoying having to navigate through all the DLC items cluttering up the shops through out the game.- CrawlersOverall a great game and one of the best survival horror games I've played. A massive improvement in almost every way over its predecessor (Which was still a really good game). Final Score - ★★★★☆

content:
Posted: January 20, 2012
												Dead Space 2 is one helluva sequel. It is indeed similar to the first game obviously, but several new elements have been added to game such as hacking. After the disaster on the USG Ishimura, DS2 now brings you to a bunch bigger place, Titan Station aka the Sprawl a huge metropolis orbiting Saturn.  The necromorphs are back and Issac Clarke is on the run from Unitology and EarthGov. Dead space 2 is also loaded with more weapons and more RIG suits to suit your preference.  However, the PC version includes all DLC except for Severed but many of the DLC suits are available free in the store. So it loses the challenge. There is also a multiplayer mode in the game which I do not recommand buying the game if you want online. This is for the story. Oh, and Issac Clarke has a voice actor now. Get this game, its also much more optimized on the PC. So no mouse aiming issues like in Dead Space 1

Моя оценка 10/10.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2011
												First, I have a deep, abiding love for System Shock 2.  It pains me to say, then, that one could legitimately call this game "System Shock 4," since EA weaseled the SS rights away from Irrational, forcing Irrational to make BioShock, which released just before Dead Space, forcing EA to rename their game and throw away their legal ownership of the System Shock franchise to avoid it becoming commonly known the shameful thing they'd done.Dead Space (1 or 2) lost the RPG elements that made SS2 so great, and added lots of "BOO!" moments, so it's more like Doom 3 clone than a System Shock 2 sequel.  So "EFF YOU" SS2 fans!  I DO like the dismemberment thing, though...Bitterness aside, Dead Space 2 looks cool, runs smoother than DS1, is more fun to play than DS1, doesn't try to startle you as much as DS1 (a lame way to be scary, IMO), pays way more homage to the SS2 style than DS1 (a huge plus for me), and was totally worth the $10 I paid for it.   You should pay $10 for DS2, too.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2013
												Dead Space 2. This game is fantastic. It has a great narrative and action that will keep you coming back for more. The controls can be edited as you see fit (unlike the first one). The graphics are nicely done and the action sequences are engaging. The story is solid with several references to the first game and the two animated movies  as well. I have now played through this game three times and it was consistently fun each time. This game has much to offer in the Third Person Perspective genre. If you are interested in a survival horror game or simply enjoyed the first Dead Space. Get it  whenever you can. I have never had the joy of the multiplayer experience as it is as DEAD as the games namesake.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2011
												Wow, amazing game. Truely amazing. The story takes place 3 years after the disaster aboard the Ishimora, and Isaac gets a little more help this time around. Dead Space 2's gameplay is quite unique! No more aim for the head for insta-kills, if youve played the previous Dead Space, you will feel right at home because melee, stompin, and stasis are all back. Theres not much to do outside of the single player, but the single player alone will last about 12 hours on a single playthrough, and if your like me, you will want to replay on Zealot mode...and that says alot. Im not one to replay single player games, but Dead Space is so different from other shooters its hard not to suit back up and blast your way through the Sprawl again. Multiplayer is Dead Space 2's biggest fault. There is only one game mode, 4v4 team objective. Survivors have to traverse the maps and accomplish objectives while the necromorphs defend them. Noobs don't get any perks, while vets have the advantage.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												While certainly not Survival-HORROR, this game can put one on edge a little, and occasionally a jump scare will get you. Even if the game doesn't scare you, the story is entertaining and the combat very fast-paced and challenging for a third person shooter. Have yet to beat the game, so this review will be updated whenI do, but so far I've had a fun, challenging ride. Note: I am playing on the second highest difficulty and only using the starting pistol, so maybe the game is actually a lot easier, but if you avoid using other items and just upgrade the pistol and armor, the game is much more interesting. Also for those complaining about the DLC items, or new players to the game, do not buy the items in the store that cost $0. They are overpowered for the game and make the beginning sections really boring. Once you get to the point that you find at least one or two armor upgrades, then I'd say the free armor is fair game because it is basically the same thing.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Enjoyable game, not as creepy as the first one, but it does have a more varied set of indoor locations than the first. I tell you this actually...i'm glad that Isaac Clarke (the protagonist of the game) was given a voice this time, cos he was mute in the first one. It's weird because they make the character mute usually so it will feel more immersive for the player, except it has the opposite effect on me, for example when the npc's talk to your character and he just blanks them it's annoying! like in half life 2 they actually have Alyx say " the quiet type huh" after Gordon doesn't respond. There are a few new monsters in this that weren't in the first like these raptoresque ones that hide behind crates and then charge at you. They only appear in rooms with big crates in them, so that's a bit formulaic, i mean it detracts from scariness if you know what the monster will be when you enter a room just by the way it's set out. Oh also that motherf*cking unkillable one that regenerates is back but only appears at the end so it's not too bad. I hate that one, it's cheap having an unkillable enemy, it's not scary but frustrating, stop it!.I preferred the ending to the first game more than this when you go down to the planet on that one, but without spoiling it i did like how the very ending of this one has a nice well not twist but like... play on how the first one ended, made me smile anyway.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												One of these rare cases where a sequel improves on amost every apect of the original without losing its core. Granted, Dead Space 2 makes you feel less vulnerable and the atmosphere of the original can't really be topped that easily, but the combat, characterization, story progression, character relatinships, enemy designs and attacks, mechanics, visuals and music, they're all absolutely fantastic in this second part. Dead Space 2 is bigger, better in several aspects, it's challenging enough without being cheap on Zealot and Hardcore and it's a hell of a lot of fun. The best thing they did was finally give Isaac a face and voice and went inside his broken mind. The Nicole sequences were always fantastic, especially the latter ones, and the Ellie banter was just great. This is pretty much the refined Dead Space experience, with the exception of the opressive and lonelier nature of the first game's constant tone. I would highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												There are some things about this game that i really enjoyed but there are a number of buts too.Like Dead Space the atmosphere was most excellent, BUT, the journey through the game was pretty-much one straight line. Oh, there were twists and turns throughout to give the illusion of a complicated Space Station etc but essentually you are rail-roaded all the wayThe combat is tough, the creatures are scary and vary enough to not get overly predictable BUT some levels are capped by stupid little Quick-Time events that break the flow and apart from the last 2 chapters fights are a simple matter of:Is this an 'encounter' room/corridor? (You can tell almost as soon as the regularily spaced doors open if this is one of 'those' rooms) Yes? Clear room No? Keep going wash rinse repeat  I did not sign on to the cr@ppy EA registration BUT still ended up having ALL the weapons and most of the Armour available to me at the very first purchase booth. There was no point hunting down schematics, it was obviously 'space Xmas' with free guns for all1st Person with the Oculus Rift would have made this game a heart-stopper BUT it is over-the-shoulder 3rd person which really weakened the experience for meI enjoyed the game. The story and back story was more than enough to keep me hooked in the whole way BUT it really just felt like playing with a 1st time  RPG Dungeon Master... "You walk down a corridor to a door, then down another corridor to another door, then loot a chest, then enter a room where X jumps out at you etc etc"

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15
												Terrific. Love this game. I think it's the best of the series.In this episode everything is perfect: story, sound, graphic, controls, interface, weapon customization interface.The developers did a great job in my opinion. I have also the other two episodes, but the first is a mess with the controls and feels clunky when moving and looking around, while the last one has a different weapon & gear's customization menu that I don't like at all (the older one was faster to navigate and more intuitive).I played Deadspace 2 on Origin first and then I decided to buy it also on Steam. If you don't have none of the three and you want to buy one, then buy this episode, you won't regret it.(in italian)Splendido. Adoro questo gioco. Penso sia il migliore della serie.In questo episodio mi sembra tutto perfetto: storia, suoni, grafica, controlli, interfaccia, interfaccia di confgurazione delle armi.A mio parere gli sviluppatori hanno fatto un ottimo lavoro. Possiedo anche gli altri due episodi della serie, ma nel primo i controlli sono un casino e ci si sente goffi quando ci si muove e si guarda intorno, mentre nel terzo hanno cambiato l'interfaccia di configurazione delle armi e non mi piace per niente (la vecchia era più intuitiva e veloce da navigare).Ho giocato Deadspace 2 prima su Origin e poi l'ho preso anche su Steam.Se non avete nessun gioco della serie e volete prenderne uno, vi consiglio questo, non ve ne pentirete.
