content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												Pros:-A variety of unique weapons that allow for slightly varied combat approaches.-An equipment custimization system that is easy to use and provides opportunity for player choice.-Some interesting puzzle elements not often found in the genre.-Visual design is quite good in most areas.-Creates a strong atmosphere of dread, terror, and horror in some areas.-Good graphics quality, even for 2015, lots of well rendered gore.Cons:-Aside from a few unique enemies, most enemy designs follow the exact same formula.-Level design is very repetitive, be prepared for many enemy-filled corridors.-The game is quite dark, and although you have a flashlight on your gun, in some areas it's just an annoyance instead of being scary.-The 3rd quarter of the game onwards gets super grindy with just tons and tons of enemies being thrown at you.-The difficulty of the game does not flow well.  In the early parts, even the difficulty above normal is easy, in the later half, even normal can be frustratingly difficult.  Higher difficulty does not really make the game more challenging in a fun way and instead simply makes to so you die way more easily.-This game is full of shrieks and loud static noises.  I had to turn the sound down because it was causing headaches.-It's a gore-fest.I am not reccommending this game because I think that in trying to be a action-horror hybrid, it falls short of each of it's parent genres in many ways.  Dead Space 2 is not a terrible game, but it is also pretty forgetable, and doesn't really excel in any way.If you are looking for a gory space horror shooter to romp through I would recommend trying to pick it up on sale for a good price (<$10) and don't be averse to playing on a low difficulty.(Note: the game comes with a bunch of free DLC weapons and armor which can trivialize the game.  If you want to have the original experience, do not purchase any weapons or armor from the store that cost 0 credits)

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
This game feels like it never endsI normally don't write reviews but since I haven't seen any review that summarised my thoughts, I'll just write this stuff down. Keep in mind this is my personal opinion and if you are among the majority of people who enjoyed this game, then good for you, you can move on.I am a Silent Hill enthusiast, I like horror games and so on but Dead Space 2 is not a scary game. Of course, most people tend to♥♥♥♥♥♥their pants whenever a light flicks but if you aren't easily scared chances are you will find this game boring, tedious and tiresome. I thought the first game wasn't too bad despite being a tad frustrating at times, but blimey I wasn't prepared for the amount of frustration this one can create.First off, if you purchased this game and you expected to play it right away, you won't. EA will ask you to login with your EA account and they will try to convince you to do so by telling you you'll miss on some 'amazing' bonus content. But you can skip that part and avoid spending an hour trying remember what password your useless EA account had. Which is nice.The game is filled with QTE which I'm not a fan of but usually don't mind. But Dead Space 2's QTE are terrible. For some reasons you can't just casually press E but you have to mash it like a maniac and still, sometimes you end up dying anyway. It's like you are meant to die and enjoy your death scene - because they put so much effort into these - and retry. My childhood was essentially me playing Metal Gear Solid so I know how to repeatedly press a single key, thanks to the torture part. Dead Space 2's QTE are essentially MGS' torture part. Every five minutes.The atmosphere of the game isn't too bad but it's completely ruined by the staggering amount of cheap jumpscares. When will game developers get that jumpscares aren't scary, they are just downright irritating. It wouldn't be so bad if they actually had just a few of them but no, the entire game is based on that. This clearly doesn't help you getting into the story, which by the way, is utterly predictable and cliché. Not once, was I even slightly surprised by any of the "plot twists". Even Dead Space 1 managed to do that.You are also expected to do every tiny bit of action which adds absolutely nothing to the experience. I can't remember how many times I asked myself "Am I actually supposed to do something or is this a cut-scene?". And sometimes, the game also expects you to figure out stupid stuff you were never asked to do before like holding E instead of just pressing it. I did every single action just by pressing E, how am I supposed to figure out for this ONE action in the game I am supposed to hold E. I am not even kidding, there's actually some bloke in the devs team who thought for this ONE SINGLE ACTION it would add a lot to the game if you had to hold E instead of just pressing it. Unbelievable.It might sound like details to you, but believe me this ruins the entire purpose of a game, which is to be enjoyable. The only thing I was looking forward to was the end, so I could just let this game rot in my Steam library and never hit the play button ever again. But guess what, those were the longest 12 hours of gameplay in my entire life. This game feels like it never ends. Not to mention they thought it'd be a brilliant idea if that massively annoying regenerating necromorph would come and chase you while dozens of enemies kept spawning all around you.I won't even mention the final boss fight*.Overall this game is a huge let down. They apparently managed to make Dead Space 3 even worse but I find it hard to believe. There are a few nice things to say about this game like the details they added into the environment and level design. Isaac feels less "stiff" and moving around feels way more natural. You can also kill babies and children which is something I wished games like Skyrim allowed you to do. But that's not enough to compete with the tremendous amount of problems this game has.*PS:The final boss fight is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥

content:
Posted: January 22
												As you go through the process of playing this game, it is clear that this game is a labor of love. The attention to detail in the enviroment, sound design, and overall design of the necromorphs makes this game some of the best sci-fi horror ever made. Every necromorph has something especially disturbing that you notice about them after the first time you see them, wether that be the way that the pukers crawl after you with a vengance after you take out their legs, or the way those walrus lookin♥♥♥♥♥necromorph's jaws are horribly distended. I highly reccomend this game for its atmosphere and chilling enemy design.Things to consider:-The game is frame locked at 30 FPS if you enable some settings in the game. I wont explain it here, but just do some quick research if it bothers you, it is very easily fixed so you can play at 60 FPS with AA.-My personal reccomendation is on your first playthrough start on the easier difficulties: That way, you can focus less on being frustrated because you are constantly dying and more on the how fast things are going to hell-If you want to win, upgrade the crap out of your plasma cutter and keep the semiconductors the game gives to ensure you always have ammo for it (sell the semiconductors and buy ammo at the shop)and dont forgetaim for the legs :)

content:
Posted: September 22, 2016
												Dead Space 2 offers the same doggedly linear levels and repetitive but engaging combat as the original, while adding a dusting of Very Serious psychodrama that may be, in both concept and execution, the least insightful portrait of grief in narrative fiction history. Neither its good ideas or its bad ones are original; it plays it safe all the way, for a game that is super polished but doesn't leave much of an impression. I'm not really mad at this game, mostly because it's nice and short and I got it on sale. So long, Dead Space 2. You were 10-ish hours of my life I will neither miss nor regret.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												Hell yeah, the sequel to the only original IP that Electronic Arts has probably made in a billion years. So the series continues its sci-fi induced survival horror gore-fest, and let me tell you, this game gives me an incredible huge boner. The best part? They fixed all the mouse issues associated with the first game so it actually controls ♥♥♥♥ing normally this time! Beyond that, the game is bloody and awesome if you like killing mutated aliens by blowing off their limbs. If you do not enjoy such activities you are probably a homosexual and enjoy riding♥♥♥♥♥♥instead. Either, Dead Space 2 ♥♥♥♥ing rocks as much as the first game.So the first thing you will notice when booting up this game is that the graphics in the game are way superior to the first. The first game looked pretty damn nice but had a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of low-resolution textures which made my♥♥♥♥♥♥sad, this is less the case with this game. Everything has graphically improved by a good generation of so and makes it much more pleasing on the eyes. The environments, while still cramped to an extent to give a greater sense of tension, have a ♥♥♥♥-ton more detail as well as being better designed. You go through various environments and they actually feel more alive, like people were once living there and you jack-off as you watch them get brutally murdered. I probably came over a thousand times just watching people die. Murder Boner. Beyond that, the environments in this game can be much more varied since you are no longer stuck on the Ishimura, which still was cool. You actually take a trip back there in the game and revisit certain old locations, but now you are aboard a space station, travelling through malls, living quarters, medical labs, outside in a big satellite and a couple of other locations. In essence, you go through a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton more environments than you did in the first game but they will have the same "space station" feel. Beyond that, the game is still filled with the bloody ♥♥♥♥ing goodness of blowing off a ♥♥♥♥ ton of limbs off of different enemies. There are some of the same enemies from the first games but abunch of new ones you get to murder in the most brutal of ways. There are now these children who attack you and I LAUGH as I blow them all away and then stomp on their corpses to get all their ammo and money! DIE ♥♥♥♥ERS DIE! While playing this game you will notice that they fixed all the problems with the mouse controls so there is no longer some weird♥♥♥♥♥input lag whenever V-Sync is turned on, and thus makes the game less irritating. The gameplay is essentially the same with you going around blowing the ♥♥♥♥ out of enemies with different guns, upgrading them and your suit with power nodes, and buying new suits and ammo, not much has changed here. One cool thing they added was the telekinesis module so that you could blow apart enemies with their own limbs. I ♥♥♥♥ing rip spikes off of dead enemies and send them through the heads of other enemies. The gameplay is still fun as balls, and not so much scary, as it is just enjoyable to blow everything away.The brutal gory death scenes still take place in the game with my favorite being the EYE STAB! You have this puzzle of focusing a laser on an eye to extract some sort of information for some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Well if you ♥♥♥♥ up it stabs out his eyeballs and the game ends with him screaming and blood flying everywhere. Haha. Enjoyable.The sound in the game is still ♥♥♥♥ing excellent with the audio soaked in reverb to give all of the audio a distant and eerie sound. It really makes the audio much more enjoyable and unique feel to it. One thing you will also notice is that Isaac talks quite a bit this time around. He no longer looks like an old man as he did in the first game and instead tells people to ♥♥♥♥ing die. Its excellent as I'm ♥♥♥♥ing mashing enemies into the ground with my mighty space boot he is yelling, "DIE YOU ♥♥♥♥ING MOTHER ♥♥♥♥ER." Brings me back the days of Kingpin when I would laugh blowing someones arm off and swearing at them at the same time. The dialog is all fairly interesting and the sound is really well done with plenty of music and ambiance to fill the game with a creepy♥♥♥♥♥atmosphere.The story continues where it left off at the first game with Isaac being used for experiments to build new markers which abunch of ♥♥♥♥ing crazy people start worshiping. Eventually, after being betrayed by pretty much everyone around you, and one of your friends getting her ♥♥♥♥ing eye stabbed out, you make your way to the marker and destroy the new one. Not too much ground is covered but you learn a little bit about the universe. The whole ♥♥♥♥ing game is great with blowing away a♥♥♥♥♥♥of enemies, using stasis to freeze them in mid-air and blow their ♥♥♥♥ing legs off. The only problem I have is the boss fight at the end was ♥♥♥♥ing simply. I just blasted the big bulbous orb with my contact beam and killed everyone. It was glorious death and gave me a boner.The game is the same gore filled fest as the first with improved graphics, controls and a bloody boner-inducing continuation of the story 9/10

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												If you liked "Dead Space" you will most likely like it's successor as well. I did not. It's not like "Dead Space 2" is complete waste of time and money. It's just... great example that putting proven elements in one jar and making game of them is simply not enough. Dark environment? Checked. But instead of creating atmosphere of fear and danger. Something chocking? Checked. This time it's necromorph infested kindergarden. And come on... How many times we saw juxtapose of defnesless and innocent kid-stuff with something gore, hoping that the contrast will hit the viewer? Generally locations are poor and repetitive. While devs managed to avoid backtracking, they did not put much work in location design and you will walka lot through mirror imige of location you were just before... More - "WTF is happening?!" strat? Checked. Been there. Done that. Dozens of times. Plot twist? Checked. Unfortunately they are so predictable... And of course - some scary paranormal stuff. Checked as well. But again, ghost of Nicole is more irritating than scary. You can barely understand what she is saying. And when you do you will realize it has little sense. "Dead Space 2" has it's strong point. Like guns. I'm pretty sure everybody will find something for themselves. Personally  I favored combination of Plasma Cutter (one of few things that are awesome), Pulse Rifle, Seeker Rifle and Javelin Gun. Also graphics quality is really good. There are also few good movie-like parts. But too few, even for such a short game. Oh, and to be honest - since Chapter 12 interesting stuff starts. But whole games has 15 chapters. And last one is pretty much just Boss fight. So yeah, "Dead Space 2" has some strong points. But they are not enough to call this games good...

content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												I was very much looking forward to playing this game. As I finally got the chance to play it, despite having it in my collection for a long while now, I played for around an hour. PROS:- The story seems very interesting.- Good graphics for its time.- Good cinematic scenes.CONS:- The camera kills this game. It was nauseating, and the fact that the camera is on the left shoulder of the character makes this game unplayable. - Lack of actual ingame options to modify makes this game feel like it's missing a lot of depth.- No actual save states - you can only save by going up to a terminal. Uhm... why are there checkpoints instead?-  During the first scene where you run, I could not for the life of me understand that you needed to press on a button to fight back a specific enemy (while in the straightjacket). I needed to go on youtube to figure out what I was doing wrong. As I was using my PC keyboard, the onscreen instructions - for some reason - did not properly appear. The fact that they couldn't even get this simple vital thing in the game... you know, onscreen instructions, made me so annoyed as I kept dying ~10 times as I tried figuring out what I was doing wrong. Which happened to be nothing, as it was the game that was improperly designed.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
												Throughout the game I was leaning towards a weak "not-recommended" rating, even though the maps were neat and there are worse ways to spend a handful of hours.  The ending of this game turned the weak "not-recommended" into a strong "do not buy this game at any price".First, at least if you are playing on a PC, this game has horrible field-of-view.  This is so the game designers can "scare" you by making monsters appear in the 320 degrees that you cannot see.  A lot of the game is swinging the view around to try and figure out where some hellspawn is shanking you with a claw.  That's a jump scare that gets old real quick.It's like a lot of other console ports, the gameplay is clunky.  However, in this game, there is zero redeeming story.  It's basically a less-playable DOOM with bad FOV.  Really nice graphics and really neat maps which is what kept me playing until the end, even though it is an unapologetic 100% corridor-shooter.And then the end, which drags on and on.  The game play changes suddenly and you die a lot.  Pretty sure the only reason for this is to show you several types of "fatality" animations for your character.  You'd think this could be interesting but you are so uninvested in the character at this point that it is simply tedious.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												I played this game immediately after finishing the first, and was almost entirely disappointed with it.Dead Space 2 takes the essentials of Dead Space 1, and then scraps everything about the first that made it immersive by giving the main character a voice. Issac can somehow make sassy remarks and sharp quips for comic relief despite being an absolute mess of a human that talks to himself and frequently yells at his long dead girlfriend.  By sacrificing Isaac's anonymity, the game is able to produce story arcs where he can bond with whoever has his frequency, which pulls entirely away from the "trying to survive and not think about all the things I'm killing" vibe and brings it closer to the "I guess I'll help this crazy guy get get off this station."  By giving Isaac a voice, the game becomes less of a game and more of an interactive movie: You are not Isaac, you are just in charge of his fate.On gameplay, the puzzles are a little more interesting, and the minigames are reduced down to just one hacking-thing, which is a step up from the original.  Combat feels almost identical to Dead Space 1, with one major exception: Kill Rooms.  You will frequently find rooms in the game where you just back into a corner and kill 15 or so enemies as they file in, which is both tedious and frustrating.  Enemies go from being a obstacles (DS1) to being switches you have to flip (dismember) so that the next room will open up so that you can do it all over again. The fighting can only be considered difficult if you find that managing your resources is also hard; as long as you have ammo, you're fine.  I played this game on survivalist difficulty, and would definetly recommend that it should not be played so, as all it seemed to do was make me sell all my extra health packs for 3 clips of ammo to blow out at the next 15 dudes due to there being almost no ammo anywhere.  Healing is never really an issue in the game, as more often than not when you are taking damage you are just going to die anyway.As a side note, the game makes a whole bunch of side-grade weapons available to you in the shop for free, which is silly as the actual weapons are expensive and require schematics to be purchased.  I only used side-grades if I had already purchased the standard copy, but there is nothing stopping you from grabbing high-teir stuff at the first shop.I played this game with a controller, as all user interface and minigames are designed to be done using joysticks, not a mouse.Relative to Dead Space 1, this is not a great game.Ignoring Dead Space 1, this game is not bad, and probably worth playing if you enjoy some sci-fi horror in your linear plot driven shooters.Expect about 12 hours of gameplay, with some replayability in newgame+ mode.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
Product received for free
												The game and the gameplay itself is legit.  Isaac Clarke became a dancer in this game if how often I make him stomp the yard (or enemies if we're splitting hairs here) is any indicator.  The environment and the overall survival-adventure genre gives your heart a steady workout as you play the game, but nothing too drastic to keep you from copping out.Despite all this however, I would have to give this game review a solid no.  And it's because the programmer for this game thought he was really funny and proceeded to ♥♥♥♥ up the programming or something for Dead Space 2.  More often than not, when you try to reload or respawn, there will be times where you will respawn empty-handed.  As in no weapons, which means not even the chance to perform melee haymakers.  You are straight up walking around empty-handed like a dumbass badass straight into a necromorph thinking you hot♥♥♥♥♥♥and all that only for you to expectedly get torn a new one.  Yes i've checked my inventory, yes i've tried to reequip my handy-dandy plasma cutter.  Nothing.  You're only option left is to reload the game again (if your dumbass saved while knowing this happened, you might very well have permanently lost that item forever unless you start a new game completely, fully-upgraded or not).  If you have really bad luck when you reload a last save, you might be caught in the loading screen forever until you decide to just quit the program itself and reload the last save (goodbye hours of progress).  But my biggest issue with this game is that for whatever the ♥♥♥♥ reason, EA thought it was a good idea to give the player every DLC weapon/armor at the start of the game, doesn't matter if you started fresh or beated the game.  From the moment you reach the first shop in the game, it's decked with weapons that can fill your inventory and armor that gives some pretty decent buffs.  Whats worse is that all of these DLC are free, no credits are needed.  If you're like me and you like the challenge of grinding through a game and actually earning your upgrades, then this is a serious turn off.  One can suggest to just ignore these free stuff and play the game as is, but the fact that these items exist at all without our say leaves a bad taste to the mouth.  There is a way to manually turn the DLC off through coding, but honestly the fact that you have to go through all that at all just to play a vanilla version of a game is jsut disgusting.  So to sum it all off, ignoring all the flaws that i've listed out, the gameplay overall is still similar to the first Dead Space we all played and enjoyed (or hated, i don't know how you roll).  It's still fun to literally curb stomp the♥♥♥♥♥♥on not just your enemies, but also dead civilians into delicious chunks.  My recommendation is that you take these complaints into serious consideration (check Google, it's not just me having these problems) and to get this game ONLY if it's on a serious sale or is given to you free.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												Amazing... Dead Space 1 was great. Dead Space 2 was something else. There was nothing wrong with Dead Space 1 but this is many times better. I am utterly speachless. I just don't know what to say.I had originally left a bad review due to extreme dificulty impeeding progression fairly early. It was at the church, there were these weirdos that gangbanged on you and they were nearly impossible. This isn't much of a spoiler by the way. If you get stuck here, make sure you get a Line Gun early on, and aim at their legs when they charge.This game actually disturbed me. The babies... They pop... There were a few WTF moments throughout the game, things like, you're just walking and SUPRISE!!!The story was actually a story this time. Isaac actually talks now. Alot of times, sequals tend to go far from what the original was. This is not the case, it is still Dead Space and you can tell. The only thing I didn't like was that there were no big bosses. In Dead Space there was Meat Wall (The Leviathan), Meat Patty (The Slug) and Wormy (The Hive Mind), and in Dead Space 2, there were a few boss like creatures but not really. I was really excited for a big♥♥♥♥♥monster like those but there was nothing really. Money is much more numerous and the ammo struggle isn't too bad. Power Nodes are everywhere now too. It used to be that you fought for every Powe Node you got. Shops are alot more complecated as well, there are fancy versions of each weapons with Pros and Cons that make it a bit confusing, there are also various suits that do that as well. This game is truely amazing. Worth every penny. I got about 9 hours off my successfull playthrough. The anoying thing is Isaacs PTSD or whatever he has. He's loony. But so am I.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												In Dead Space™ 2, you join Isaac Clarke, the Systems Engineer from Dead Space, as he wakes up three years after the horrific events on the USG Ishimura. The Ishimura was a Planetcracker-class starship besieged by grotesque reanimations of its dead crew, known as “Necromorphs.” After unearthing a strange artifact known as the Marker, Isaac finds himself on the Sprawl, a giant space station in orbit around Saturn. Unable to remember how he got here and plagued with demented visions of his dead girlfriend Nicole, he must survive another nightmarish outbreak of Necromorphs as he fights his way towards an answer he hopes will end all the chaos.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												My hat is off to the developers and producers. Dead space 2 goes above and beyond the original game in every way. Its atmosphere, scope, storytelling, and user interaction are all flawless. Visceral Games is on fire with this title and i especially give a nod to the team developing the multiplayer experience. great work all around. my only complaint is the difficulty in the game. any gamer capable of keeping a cool head and fire accurately is going to find the default difficulty WAY too easy. The first game suffered from this as well. While its not a major gripe, i feel the lower difficulty takes away from the horror at times. Thankfully the harder settings are ready to go from the start. On a positive note, Visceral did a great job in giving the player a reason to use the collection of weapons they made. In the first Dead Space, the plasma cutter is by far the most powerful weapon and competitive players disregarded the other weapons, selling off other ammo in favor of power nodes and plasma rounds. However, by diversifying enemy types and weaknesses they have given the player viable alternatives which diversifies gameplay and lets the player have a reason to use the otherwise ignored weapons. (which are all very flavorful and very well designed.) great job. definitely a must have. 9/10

number of helpful: 5 of 16 people (31%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												Dead Space 2 starts as a promising survival horror, but ultimately ends up being a generic, mindless shooting gallery, where one ambush is followed by another. The game is littered with closed doors that conveniently open the moment you clear the X number of enemies that spawn on you upon triggering a swarm event.The scariest thing in this game is probably the random noise you hear every now and then, till you realize its made by objects that are glitching in walls. The locations are pretty generic, often consisting of the same rooms and layouts copy-pasted together. Thoughout the story you will often be interrupted by unskippable video transmissions and hallucitations, in during which you are unable to progress due closed doors (which are open the moment everyone is done talking), so if you don't really care about the story or got killed and forced to restart a segment, then it will gets more and more irritating towards the end. The game is roughly 10 hours, and even less if you're playing on lower difficulty or don't look every in every nook and cranny, but despite its relatively short length it overstays its welcome. Get it on a discount or not at all. PROS- Visuals. The lighting in particular is quite impressive - Sound and voice actingCONS- Generic, repetitive shoot-em-up- Unskippable cutscenes and annoying, frequent video transmissions- Predictable jump scares and ambush locations

number of helpful: 6 of 19 people (32%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												It's more linear, it's more cinematic, it wastes more of your time, it destroys the story and the gameplay is poorer. It's generally just worse in every imaginable way.Where before you could wander around a bit and explore each section you are now driven down a straight line with occasional loot chests "hidden" behind a short dead end turn. The excellent pacing is gone in favor of shoving cutscenes down your throat every five minutes.The gameplay is faster and more intense, in a system that isn't made for speed. Favoring memorization of enemies that will instakill/bumrush you over any kind of tactics or skill. Jumpscares will now gib you where the first game had the sense not to throw cheap deaths at you that you couldn't avoid.Zero G doesn't work that way, good night.The story contradicts the first game and adds nothing of value. All the way up until the end it is never made clear what is going on and you are left wondering who the villian is and why he is the villian. It fails to understand even simple concepts established in the first game, instead misrepresenting and retconning them as taken at face value.Additionally, the Steam version gives you late game stuff for free right off the bat. Making the game far easier than it needs to be.If Dead Space is Alien, this game most assuredly is Alien 3, complete with butchering of an earlier Earth invasion storyline that would actually have been good.

number of helpful: 0 of 7 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 25, 2016
												Bulls#$%. Fake. Difficulty.I hate it in games. It makes things harder, not by being challenging or clever, but by pulling every cheap, irritating trick possible. Dead space 2 is loaded with the stuff, and it angers me more because I enjoyed the first game so much. Once in a great while, Dead Space 1 would pull something like a monster attacking me just as I left a save point. I'd be startled and think, 'Oh, you goofy guys! Ya got me!'But when something like that happens SO OFTEN in Dead Space 2, I began to EXPECT to be attacked pretty much any time I was asked to concentrate on moving an item, hacking a lock, or repairing a macguffin. It's not scary. It's not even startling anymore. There's just the cringe of anticipation, the monster pops up, you kill it, then get back to the stupid puzzle you gotta solve so you can move onto the next room with another stupid puzzle and another jack-in-the-box monster.Worst of all? The enemies are magic and scouting is useless. Meaning, you can visually verify that a room is empty, and enemies will still spawn in. You can back yourself in a corner, and enemies will somehow spawn behind you. You can come from a room that was completely sealed, and enemies will STILL spawn behind you. To the best of my memory, the first game did not do this. Enemies would jump out at you from hiding spots, but once you killed them off, they didn't keep on reappearing just because the room wasn't finished being difficult.Perfect example: I fought my way through two red rooms that had no less than six enemies spawn in as soon as I turned a corner. Then, at the end of this, there was a LARGE, OPEN, COMPLETELY EMPTY room with a hacking minigame in it. I knew exactly what would happen. Soon as I started the minigame, I was bashed out of it by a gigantic monster that had somehow entered the completely empty room behind me without making a sound.BULLS#$%. FAKE. DIFFICULTY.Maybe if I'd just played DS2 by itself I wouldn't be as disgusted with it. But I just finished DS1 a few days ago and wrote a glowing review. Specifically, I mentioned DS1's immersion. The ship felt like a real ship that existed in physically-possible dimensions. DS2 is simply a long line from start to end. I thought the linearity would just be for the opening chapters until the familiar gameplay kicked in. Nope! Whereas in the first game, each chapter felt like you were accomplishing something, in DS2, all you're doing is scampering around trying to find someone who'll tell you what the hell is going on. It felt for half the game like I was just waiting to get to the part that mattered. And the blatantly-impossible monster spawns further broke any illusion that I was playing in a real world that existed. I wasn't seeing a space station orbiting Saturn: I was seeing a bunch of game devs setting up the next prank-like 'screw you' for the player. I stopped caring about anything that happened and finished the game only to be able to say I didn't quit.Though to be fair, let me list some positives: Graphics are better. The suits look great. The mall and daycare were visually-interesting designs. I loved the part with the drill machine. All of the zero-G sections were great and much-improved from the first game. And, to my pleasant surprise, there is a character who I grew to truly hate over time, and the game eventually let me murder the living daylights out of them. A small moment of catharsis. Nice.Overall though, Dead Space 2 is like any number of bad movie sequels. It tries to be better by throwing more action and danger at the story, but utterly fails to spend time appreciating the subtle things that made the first one work.If one of the best parts of your game is when you basically just replay the original for a few levels, you've screwed up.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2016
												I enjoyed the first part of the series, but this one was disappointing. The first half of the game was good enough, but after that the game just becomes too repetitive. You start noticing how you are again entering another room which will soon be filled with enemies and you're forced to get rid of 5-10 necromorphs. Towards the end these rooms are more frequent and the number of enemies higher, making the game more of an action game than an atmosphere based horror game. There are also other aspects that break the immersion of a doomed space station with other people and constantly remind you that events are only triggered by your character.This game has some memorable moments and some aspects, like zero gravity, have been refined for a smoother gameplay. Upgrading your gear is also interesting, as upgrade parts are rare and everything cannot be upgraded fully in one playthrough. The gear handling is a bit pointless though, as 90 % of ammunition drops from enemies are for the currently equipped weapons. Because of this you can pretty much choose your favorite weapons and not have to switch gear based on what's available.The sound effects and music also do their job well. The graphics are still pretty nice to watch almost seven years after the game's release.

Dead Space 2: 5/10 Not RECOMMENDEDDead Space 2 Impressions:This is a nice game and yes it is better then the first... or is it?It does have better graphics, it seems to have better controls... but something is off. It just does not feel as authentic as the first one... and it is (as the first one) highly repetetive... the story is... whatever... not really important... the circumstances are forced...What is cool, are the new Z-gravity controlls, this is a nice addition, that should habe been in the first one.This is a nice game... get it on sale... do not believe the hype... but I will not recommend this.On a side note... Only EA knows how to punish you with free DLC... you get some mighty weapons and armor right from the start FOR FREE because the game comes with some lame DLC pack that includes those. It does not really breake the game, but surely goes against the intended survival aspect and it does make the store window overcrowded with useless items.

												More humans-turned-aliens pop out of walls and yell "boo" at you in their language in every other room or so. The gameplay is kind of fun, the story has a few interesting bits but overall is still just as forgettable as the original- not to mention the ending fight is just insultingly stupid. At this point it feels as if they're intentionally holding pieces of the story out for other media [Comics or movies] in order to milk more money out of this. In a confusing turn, they gave you the ability to buy multiple suits and variatons on weapons, which felt like they artifically padded out the list of useless weapons [Can beat the game fine with just Plasma Cutter, I've done it with both games] and suits so they could use them for a bullet point on the back of the box.tl;dr - kind of fun to play, completely fails in every way as a horror and/or story driven game. Probably would be better as a simple survive-the-waves game.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
												Well, I decided to purchase this as it was on offer.I've already requested a refund after just 17 minutes!Why you may ask.1. The game defaults to 1024 x 768, not your monitors native resolution.This meant, for me, that the registration menu (which you stupidly have to complete BEFORE you're allowed to change resolution) was only half showing on the screen, meaning I was guessing and hoping that my input was going into the correct box.After struggling with it for over 5 minutes I eventually had it done, only to be told that the email was invalid, so I just skipped it and decided to try the single player, after all I could always reregister later.2. At the start of the single player game you're forced to sit through a video, which you can't skip, of about 3 minutes, not long you might say, but long enough, after my earlier problems, to amke me♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off and irritable, another minus point then!3. Eventually, when the game started, the controls were all messed up and constantly rotating, even though I'd reconfigured them before starting, so I got killed and there was nothing I could do about it.4. Restarted and guess what, had to sit through the video again!I didn't bother, I'm not going through all that again to have the same problems.To sum it up, a very frustrating experience and one I have no wish to repeat.You have to ask why the developer forces the game to default to 1024 x 768 instead of your monitors native resolution? I have a 144hz refresh rate monitor and that refresh rate is available via the options menu, which makes it all the more frustrationg and mystifying?There is, quite possibly, a decent game here but I'm not prepared to wade through loads of initial problems, due to shoddy programming, to begin with, then being kicked in the teeth by being forced to sit though a bloody video that I've already seen, through no fault of my own!Buy at your own risk!0 out of 10Shoddy and inexcusable!

number of helpful: 2 of 19 people (11%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17
												Like the first Dead Space, extremely linear and heavily scripted.  No variation at all in the game play.  You go in a straight line from one point to another.  Achieve your minor fetch quest get attacked by monsters.  Go to the next minor fetch quest, get attacked by monsters and so forth.  Similar to many unimaginative games like this it’s basically a 20 minute game stretched out utilizing insignificant fetch requests.   This game was clearly slapped together quickly to capitalize on the success of the first.  Game play is the same as the first absolutely no extra effort is put into this game.  Even when you get killed and have to replay that scene again the creatures attack from the very same spot, so you know where they are coming from.  The developers don't even bother to try mixing it up, it always the same.  You could almost see the script running in front of your eyes.  You even go back to the original ship from the first game thereby allowing the lazy developers to reuse assets.  Without a doubt, this is one of the laziest games I ever played.  The graphics are minor step up from the first and that's the only thing that has improved.  The character Isaac now speaks and he sounds like he's about 16 years old.  But he still moves like he's an old geezer who filled up his depends.  The shooting mechanics were abysmal in this game.  None of them were consistent in the damage they caused.   For instance a heavily modified Line Gun could kill a creatures at 20ft. away with one blast but requires 3 blasts if they are 5ft in front of you.  Except for the Ripper, I found this inconsistency in most of the weapons.  I found the same problem with Stasis.  The fact that the game even uses a gimmick like stasis, tells me that the developers know it’s an inconsistent shooter.  I don't know how many times a creature was in front of Isaac and nothing would happen none of the weapons would fire.  It was like Isaac was scared stiff and instead of trying to firing he just stood there filling his depends.  The only horror I found in the game was in the extreme linearity and bad controls.  I also think the developers could have better utilized their time by trimming down Isaac’s elaborate death scenes and put that same effort into creating something more practical, let’s say, I dunno, maybe a more original game?In conclusion I can't believe that a game created in 2011 that still uses tank controls on the main character can get such high reviews.  The character can't duck or climb all he can do is go left/right/backward/forward.  There is absolutely no variation in the gameplay whatsoever, it’s excruciatingly linear. This has to be the laziest way to create a game.  But I can only speak for myself and if you thought the original Dead Space was a wonder to behold then you will probably be giddy with joy with this sequel.  Anyone else looking for something more than a Resident Evil wannabe set in space should look elsewhere.

												Just play resident evil 4 instead. This is just that but with an unintenionally stupid story rather than a camp masterpiece that came out 10 years ago yet still is superior. It is so clear that the designers of this played and enjoyed resi 4, but do not understand what made it work. It has the over the shoulder style shooting and closed in enviroments like in resi , but it misses out the other components for it to be complete. In resi 4, you run faster than enemies, so there is always an option to run and regroup. In dead space all enemies run faster than you, so the only choice is to not miss. In resident evil 4, the levels are designed so there is always an escape route, or a ladder to climb, or a place to drop down to. In dead space, there are corridors...and sometimes a table. Thats your level design. Another problem is that there is no personality to anyone in this. Im still not sure if isaac is voiced by nolan north or not, and the xenomorphs are absolutely in no way zombies how dare you make that accusation!? By tedious comparrison, leon had a goofy b movie charm to him and the boss characters were introduced, given plenty of screen time to convey their personality, and as such when the boss fight rolls around it has more intimacy, compared to dead space 2 which just has an alien not zombie thats bigger and has one extra ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t undodgable attack, so they by default are the boss fight i suppose.It may feel silly to just compare this to resident evil 4 but considering how much they clearly wanted to be compared to resident evil 4 (which is like a movie wanting to be judged alongside die hard. not brave. ♥♥♥♥ing suicidal), i cant help it. The combat is fundamentally fun because the sound design is solid and the visuals are great, but if youre looking for any substance, nah.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
												I'm no fan of the Dead Space games. In fact, I detest them. Dead Space 1 was, in a word, boring. Boring to the point that I barely remember anything about it. I remember the turret segments, which should have been awesome, were ruined by the atrocious controls, and I remember the two other people with Isaac being unlikeable jackasses. I haven't played Dead Space 3, and I really don't want to. Now, Dead Space 2 takes a cue from Empire Strikes Back and attempts to be better than the first game, which it manages to both succeed and fail at. The Sprawl is a great location to play through, being far more spacious and varied than the Ishimura, and we get a few glimpses of everyday life on the Sprawl. Isaac himself actually has characterization this time, albeit fairly clichéd, and most of the characters we interact with have different and compelling personalities, especially newcomer Ellie. Ellie and Isaac play off one another in ways that are both hilarious and heartbreaking, and it overall makes for better immersion.Unfortunately, that's all I have to say that's positive. The biggest, most glaring problem is: this game is basically Dead Space 1 with a new paint job and a camper attached. Most of the enemies are copy-pasted from the first game, including the "elite" recolors, gameplay is identical, the plot amounts to "Dead Space 1, but on a space station," the wide array of weapons is, again, completely pointless since the plasma cutter is all you really need, Isaac is lead along by a female character who betrays him in sight of the oh-so-special Marker, (two this time!), and the monsters keep jumping out of the exact same "vent" (it doesn't actually go anywhere) as the first game. Oh, but wait! Now, there's extra varieties of incredibly obvious panels the monsters could be behind! Yahoo!Now, onto the series' bread and butter; the gore and body horror. They're there and they're certainly creative, but they start losing what edge they might have had when they're in your face (literally) from the start of the game right up to the end. Much of the game's gore allowance was lavishly slapped onto Isaac's numerous death scenes...which you'll likely never see if you play at all competently.In conclusion, Dead Space 1 is boring, Dead Space 2 is better but still boring, and Dead Space 3 doesn't look like it's worth the money spent.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 8
												Dead Space 2 was a pleasant surprise for me. Which is odd considering it is a game all about dismembering nightmarish alien monstrosities in the sci-fi equivalent of a haunted house; pleasant is hardly the adjective I might expect to use. But after the disappointing experience I had with the first game of this franchise, it was a welcome change.The biggest improvement was to what I consider the major failing of the first game: Dead Space 2 is actually a creepy experience. Scary? Well, I might be too jaded for that (and let's face it, the monsters in this series are just too comic book to inspire real terror) but I'll admit some of its scripted sequences did make me jump in my seat (just a little bit, of course). The levels are meticulously designed, with excellent lighting and some good texturing, all of which work together to set the proper mood. And while the story and characters are also still sophomoric it was head and shoulders above the simple fetch-quests by characterless officers of the first game.The gameplay was improved too, leaning more towards pure action run-n-gun and discarding most of the chaff of the survival-horror genre (with the exception of save-points -whose presence I accept since I felt they heightened the tension of the game- and the limited inventory space, which I despised since it was a pointless and tedious bit of micro-management that distracted from the game's otherwise impressive pacing). The AI was a satisfactory mix of predictable and chaotic, interspersed with a handful of the mostly scripted sequences.Oh, there were a few rough edges; some levels overstayed their welcome, for instance and there were a handful of minor bugs but on the whole I can't look too unfavorably at this latest iteration of the Dead Space franchise. Its a good-looking, well-playing game with lots too see, even more to kill and lots of memorable (and often creepy) moments.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2012
												Dead Space 2 is the most satisfying sequel i've played since Half-Life 2 happened. Comparatively the two games are quite similar too in terms of how their respective story lines have developed since the events of the first games. To this end, Dead Space 2 is every bit as good as the first game only, bigger, flashier, shinier, more explosive and more intense.Yes, the once faceless and largely mute Issac now drops his mask more than a bride does her dress on her wedding night and speaks to camera during cut scenes a good amount which does start to wear a bit thin but it doesn't do it enough to spoil the game. It does also verge slightly on having too many of the 'tap the button to escape certain peril' but again EA pushed just past the line but not so far as to actually de-tract from it being an awesome game.If you liked the first, you have to play this. If you haven't played the first, buy it, play it and then come back and buy this one!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 28, 2011
												THIS IS A GREAT SEQUEL. YOU SHOULD BUY IT.The gameplay starts off by absolutely throwing you right into the thick of things in the most wonderful way possible, then it gradually fades back into Dead Space 1 style gameplay, where things never stop going wrong.Atmosphere is improved, and some areas have actually had a splash of colour added for good effect.It's a little disappointing that all the quicktime events are accomplished by either aiming and firing before something bad happens, or mashing the E key before something equally bad happens... but otherwise they're wonderfully executed. Not too many of them, but not too few either.And of course Dead Space 2 has more than one tip of the hat to events in Dead Space 1. You really get the most out of them if you've played the first game.The team who developed this managed to characterise Isaac Clarke really well with dialogue, so there's no need to be put off by the silent protagonist suddenly gaining a voice.

												Dead space 2 is the successor and full body improvement to Dead Space, Both are masterpieces and peak examples of the survival horror genre, toped only by such works as (the) Resident evils and Silent hills. Mechanically the game is brilliant, building on regional hit boxing it one ups and makes the player dismember entire limbs, ligaments and portions of enemy bodies, its character design is absolutely original grotesque and scary, with fine details taken from photographs of real car crash victims, Ontop of that the game is packed with unique yet feasible fictional weapons, from construction and mining utility tools converted into deadly tools of dismemberment to military heavy weapons and amours. Really quite the masterpiece. Packed with lore and explanation for every aspect.

Posted: November 30, 2013
												90% - Welcome Isaac Clarke aboard the Sprawl!Dead Space 2 continues the story of the great horror sci-fi game, Dead Space. As engineer Isaac Clark, the protagonist of the first episode, you'll wake up in a mental sanitarium of the Space Station Sprawl three years after the Ishimura incident and while you awake into the same deadly nightmare you've experienced aboard the planet cracker ship, you'll have to learn what has happened in those missing years and how is it possible that the necromorphs came back after you've eliminated the threat in the past.One of the greatest improvement of Dead Space 2 is that the developers have cured Isaac's sure throat and finally he is capable to speak all over the game. The other greater improvements of the game, other than the great graphics which is finally much more colorful than the graphics of the first, that the game does not have any loading screen at all. The game loads at the beginning and up from that moment you won't see a single loading screen at all. The whole game plays fluid and without any interuption from the beginning to the very end. However not everything is perfect in Dead Space 2. The story is a bit weaker than the storyline of the original Dead Space, some of the twists are predictible at times and the characters are also a bit weaker than the core team of the USG Kellion.While Dead Space 2 is supposed to be a horror game the horror factor is slowly vanishing by time, mostly in the first quarter of the game and you have to realize that the game is more of an action game than a horror. And if you play Dead Space 2 right after the first one, you'll see this right from the beginning as you will have the routine to not be scared, but to eliminate the necromorphs easily with a smile on your face. Especially with the new weapons, which are even better than the unique weapons of the first one. Dead Space 2 is a great game, but in my humble opinion its more of an action game than a horror and unfortunately it is not better than Dead Space. Still it is highly-highly recommended.

												I would have said it would be pretty impossible to beat the original Dead Space in terms of have a brilliantly visualised world with enough variety, thrills and scares. I was wrong. DS2 is an easy contender for best game ever. Where it loses points for familiarity (having played the original a few times) it regains them for the stunning scenery, original storyline, and cutscene animations. Theres enough action to keep die-hard shoot em fans happy but plenty of variety in the little mini sequences (i.e. fling through space)So definitely one of the best games out there. Will score a very healthy 9 our of 10

												Dead Space 2 is a very good game. Despite some nitpicks I think it's developing into a really great series, and definitely worth playing. Two caveats: if you want a challenge play on a higher difficulty than normal; and don't expect to be terrified. Definitely play the first one first, as well; the second one does include a “last time on Dead Space” intro, but the first game is worth experiencing, especially now that it's dropped in price. And DEFINITELY play all the way to the end, because the ending does a great job of both wrapping things up and raising the stakes at the same time.Full review here: http://postlaunch.blogspot.ca/2011/10/dead-space-2.html

The graphics were much more detailed while not sluggish at all.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												If you've played the first dead space then this one is a must! If you haven't I suggest getting the bundled pack as some of the horror elements might not resonate as strongly with you (I.E the return of the immortal necromorph or the giant necromorph plant in the hallway). This game really capitalizes on the mechanics of the first game and succeeds it fairly well. It has a nice combination of horror and action sequences that make for fluid gameplay and story. Dead space 2 really puts the player in do or die situations by forcing them to remove or shoot off specific parts of enemies so they don't revive. This becomes all the more tricky when surrounded by various enemies as each enemy is unique and MUST be disposed of in a specific way. The story of this one is okay but not great. My only compliant about the game is the last fight which felt like a cope out and was very simplistic compared to the rest of the game. Overall though I give it a 9/10 and recommend it to horror buffs.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
												Now I can't say that I played this game on the PC, so this won't be a performance review.  However, that being said. I gladly say that this was some of the best time invested into a survival horror game in a long time.  Not once does it let up, from jump scares to just a creepy atmosphere the single player campaign had me coming back more and more to hunt down the several achievements and master each difficulty, and the multiplayer was a surprisingly intense gorefest where two teams of four are pinned against eachother, one team being the humans trying to complete an object, and the other a swarm of necromorphs whos sole goal is to stop the humans in their tracks. However, while the game is very fun that doesn't mean that the core elements are always present.  This is expecially noticed in the single player. While the beginning is loaded with jump scares and an overall sense of dread as ou walk through the dark corridors, the latter isn't as promising. The dark corridors aren't so dark and the overall pace picks up, giving it a more action based feel than that of a survival horror game. I personally loved Dead Space 2, even with it not holding up in certain aspects it was a very polished game with tons of replayability with the strategic multiplayer and intense single player.  I mark this game as my favorite game for that year and one of my favorite games of all time.  Worth a playthrough atleast for any survival horror fan.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												I originally played this on Xbox 360 before I made the move to PC gaming. I think its actually impossible to be scared by DS2, so long as you played the first game first. In DS1 Isaac never spoke, it made it feel like the NPC's were talking directly to you, the player, it put you fully in his shoes, YOU were the character. For me that was what made the original Dead Space so immersive and so f***ing terrifying - that and the horrifying man in the wall monsters.They threw that out of the window in this one by having Isaac talk, sure it makes sense from a story point of view but it takes you out of his shoes and completely detaches you, makes you an outsider looking in, like any other game.That gripe aside this is still an awesome game, graphically a lot better than the first, hacking up necromorphs and impaling them with their own limbs is still as satisfyingly gruesome, and the stomping has been improved, now instead of one thud at a time you can keep on mashing that stomp until Isaac gets all angry and swears at the gloopy corpse under his feet. Another big improvement over the first is the zero G sections, where in the first game you'd have to slowly jump from point to point, in DS2 you now have full 360 degree flight with reaction thrusters on your suit, and this has been incorporated into some great puzzles involving the stasis module, pipes and fans.It still has its spooky moments and unexpected googlieman surprises but they lack the impact of the first game, and after an hour of playing you'll be completely desensitized to it. Well most of it, that man in the wall monster is back in this one too and he is still f***ing terrifying.Absolutely worth the buy.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Horror in a haunted house has an escape plan called a door. Even horror on water can lead you to dry land. But in space, if you get out, where can you go? Dead Space 2 exemplifies this despair and pushes the protagonist, Isaac Clarke, to insanity.StoryAfter the events onboard the USG Ishimura, Isaac finds himself in a psyche ward of a space station called the ‘Sprawl’, which is located on Saturn’s moon Titan, a moon famous for its thick atmosphere. After a harrowing introduction, you discover the alien necromorphs from Dead Space have arrived as well as Isaac. You are briefly tutored on the familiar third-person controls and Isaac regains his suit, his mining tools and stasis and kinesis abilities. What proceeds is a terrifying experience that takes you on a journey through Titan station with surprising twists, turns with many horror clichés from the first game subverted and contorted into new styles of horror.The atmosphere is thick with dread at every corner with save points being a god-send. The setting brings new ideas to the formula as Titan station was once a living, working permanent residence for workers and family. Far from the USG Ishimura’s cold steel, functional, workingman’s mining vessel, Titan has schools, shopping centres, churches, apartments, bars, clubs, restaurants all with colours and stylish architecture. Although some of the colour is blood red and still quite fresh. The eerie premise that not too long ago this station was sprawling with civilians is echoed throughout the game.GameplayThe over-the-shoulder perspective bares resemblance to Resident Evil 4 and Gears of War and all HUD is incorporated into the suit via light levels with the menu and inventory screen brought up as a holographic display. Isaac’s movement is slow due to his heavy mining suit but his gravity boots offer stomping abilities that turn necromorph corpses to mush. Instead of upgrading the standard suit, new suits can be purchased with credits at vendors around the station and your rig is upgraded at work benches using nodes. The more expensive suits can provide stronger armour with lighter material to increase Isaac’s flexibility when severing limbs. Removing limbs from necromorphs is still the best way of progressing and available to Isaac’s arsenal is several mining tools that serve well as limb cutters with traditional weapons, formally used by security personal, available on the station.The gameplay of strategic dismemberment is incredibly satisfying and experimenting with combining different tools on different types of necromorphs offers huge variety. Stasis was less relied upon in this game other than coping with bosses and puzzles but when dealing with smaller enemies it was useful to have kinesis to fire objects in order to preserve ammo. On the Zealot difficulty ammo is very scarce and precision and tactics are required at every step. Zealot is the difficulty to play on but playing on the Hardcore setting limits you to only 3 saves throughout the game if you are a crazy enthusiast who wants to be punished. New abilities include Isaac’s suit being able to be controlled with short bursts of thrust in zero gravity zones inside and outside the station. This made the zero-G zones a joy rather than the frustrating surface to surface thrust jumps in Dead Space.Being sucked out of space is a constant hazard that can also be a risk/reward. When there is a lookout window in an area, the glass can be shot out to suck all occupants, including you, out of the room but if Isaac is quick enough he can shoot an emergency shut down switch that raises a blast door. But leave it too late and the blast door will chop you in half. In fact, Isaac is subject to some of the most brutal death scenes in any game. The huge variety of deaths is staggering and the violence is fantastically visceral. Perhaps that’s why Visceral Games renamed themselves from EA Redwood Shores after the first game.TechnicalSound and lighting were Dead Space 2’s biggest technical achievements. The sound of Isaac screaming or shrills of a Stalker charging or even the electronic noises of walking near ammo, doors and recharging stasis is embedded into my mind and I can still hear them now. Isaac’s heavy boots on metal grating echoes through the station and the pulsating movement of machinery surges through the headphones. The zero-G sections also cleverly avoid sound with only the vibrations of shooting and jumping reverberating through Isaac’s suit further emphasizing the hostility of space. The lighting uses a terrifying blend of darkness and flashing bright lights and also soft candlelight and it’s some of the best lighting I’ve ever seen. The framerate is solid, the art design is stunning, the textures are crisp but due to the layout of the suit’s menus, it’s recommended to use an Xbox 360 controller.VerdictDead Space 2 is a sick, twisted, frightening experience that oozes tension due to its fantastic lighting, sound and satisfying gameplay.90%

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Isaac has lost his mind after what he experienced on the Ishimura, and some have taken an interested in this lost mind.This time around, Isaac feels like an actual person because of his dialogue and interaction with others.Old enemies types return, new enemies arrive, and combat is still chaotic as hell.Resources seem moderate at first, then slowly dwindle as challenges peak.The graphics are worth screenshots at times, especially to catch that great glimpse of shocking gore.Stressful situations and paranoia will make you jump, so get comfy and turn off the lights.Sounds emphesizing an attack, guttural voices and monster yells, all make for a terrifying experience.The game does not feel short but can be beaten in about 10 hours on the first play through.A great sequel to the series that's just as good as the first.If you are a fan of horror action then this game is perfect!Certain weapons feel worthless, but there is a possibility that they may have value if fully upgraded.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
												Having played the Demo for 360 a number of times, I decided that when Dead Space 2 came on sale, that it was time to try the full game out. Now, having played through the entire game, it has entered the select roster of my favourite games. As it stands, I would be prepared to pay £40 for this game. Right from the very beginning, the quivering threads of fantastically engineered tension captured me. The fear was vivid, real, and made me feel passionate, engaged and worried about a campaign and characters like I have not done in a long time. The only thing that I can even complain about is that sometimes, when aiming with enemies directly in front of my weapon (behind crosshairs) the shots went through them. However, this affected me roughly twice over about ten hours of solid gameplay. An utterly fantastic campaign. I'd buy it for that alone, forget the multiplayer. 10/10

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Dead Space 2 is a very good game. Despite some nitpicks I think it's developing into a really great series, and definitely worth playing. Two caveats: if you want a challenge play on a higher difficulty than normal; and don't expect to be terrified. Definitely play the first one first, as well; the second one does include a “last time on Dead Space” intro, but the first game is worth experiencing, especially now that it's dropped in price. And DEFINITELY play all the way to the end, because the ending does a great job of both wrapping things up and raising the stakes at the same time.Full review here: http://postlaunch.blogspot.ca/2011/10/dead-space-2.html

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												Dead Space was a pretty good game in its own right even though the USS Ishimura was essentially the Event Horizon, a ship where nothing could possibly go right for anyone at any time at all.  Titan is a welcome relief, as the outer space shopping mall getting trashed by the demonic and deadly is a fun little aside as you get your insides pulled out by a necromorph.  Issac Clarke's personal torment is ramped up and the dream sequences are all really well done.  Gratuitous, well-programed and even though it's not all that scary, certain moments that caught me off guard were really effective.

												I've finished dead space 1 & 2. So I know the difference between the gameplay. If you played dead space one and like it. The story adds onto it and makes it very interesting til the point you're like "The .... just happen!?" Therefore the story is good. The controls in DS1 where ok but the controls in two are much better. Instead of one stomp, you can literally stomp than your hear is satisfied in DS2 and I'll let you know that Issac speaks his mind when stomping. The weapons are better which I suggest upgrading the plasma cutter all the way til you get the bonus; it'll be familiar and your best weapon first time through. I had mines fully upgraded til chapter 7/8 and it made killing necromorphs easier as it added fire to each shot. My second weapon was the line gun. Anyhow good game.I liked the fact that certain items are available from the start (based weapons and suits).I liked stomping my enemies to my hearts desire (Loved the fact that he spoke his mind).Loved the controls (controller is much better).Story has been good since one.Also if you played chapter one and you play this long enough. You might get freaked out later on in the game. I turned it off because I was literally tripping.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2012
												Dead Space 2 é um jogo de cair o cu da bunda de tão tenso que é. O jogo tem um equilíbrio muito bom entre ação e terror, com um ótimo rítmo. Os gráficos são lindos, e os cenários muito bem detalhados. Cada área da estação Sprawl é de um jeito. Você nunca vai encontrar uma área repetida e são raríssimas vezes que você passa pelo mesmo lugar duas vezes, e nunca mais que duas. A história é excelente e te amarra até o final. Tem até um pouco de drama. Isaac Clarke é um excelente protagonista, com personalidade, voz, e isso faz dele um engenheiro mais bad♥♥♥♥♥do universo. To roubando várias opiniões do meu amigo Demolution, que tudo que cantou do jogo é vero e concordo plenamente. JOGUEM. E joguem depois de jogar o Dead Space 1, que também é um♥♥♥♥♥♥jogo de terror.

												A good sequel to the original Dead Space that emphasises combat over the first games more unsettling tone. That's not to say that Dead Space 2 doesn't have it's share of jump scares and tense atmosphere because it does feature one of the greatest chapters in a game since Dead Space. Further expanding upon Isaac Clarkes dealing with the Marker and the Necromorphs revealing answers asked in the original game but also introducing more questions. Imaginitive set pieces and some great enemy design make this a worthy sequel. 8/10

												It's cheap. It's fun. It's scary. It plays better than the first one. It has more weapons. It has more suits. It has improved on everything the community wanted, or at least that I wanted. It kept the ability to replay the game and upgrade all your weapons, like the first one. So if you fell in love with the first one, you'll be doing all that again and then some with this one. AND FOR GOD'S SAKE IT'S $15 TODAY ON THE SUMMER SALE YOU IDIOT!

content:
Posted: September 15, 2011
												An exciting, dark atmospheric shooter horror game. The game opens with the man who came to free you from an insane asylum ward turning into a Necromorph inches from your face while you're still in a straight jacket...RUN! And survive. The rest of the game you itch your trigger finger plenty, slicing limbs off infected like it's going out of style throughout a sprawling infected city built into an asteroid floating through space while rarely breaking immersion beacuse the HUD is just a hologram built into Isaac's suit. The sleek design is worth stopping to appreciate - although it's not up to Bioshock levels of artistry it is a true step up from almost any other shooter.The 'ghost' of your dead wife haunts you in demensia hallucinations until the very end of the game - when all is revealed.A suggestion - Play as Isaac the Amputator and upgrade the heck out of your basic Plasma Cutter, your first and most trustworthy friend in this infected city.

												A really scary game that brings the frights and thrills that you would expect from the Dead Space series. The story is continued in this one from the first Dead Space. The story's great, the graphics and sounds bring you into the story, the overall game is very well done. Issac gets some new suits and new gear to aide him in his battle to destroy the marker, and he picks up some friends along the way.I highly recommend this game to anyone ready for a good fright and an in depth great story. Just make sure to always have your gun ready to fight because monsters come from the most random spots. If you get this you wont regret it!

												It is fair to compare this to the first Dead Space.  - Its an action/horror game in the third person.  While the controls feel clunky, they actually work to make you feel as though you cannot control everything, thus making the game a bit more horror than precise control games.  The quality, graphics, and general gameplay are exactly like Deadspace 1 - both games about 7-9 hours each with simple upgrade mechanisms.  The guns themselves are very fun and satisfiying to use.  The cons to this game is that you feel no real sense of progression as each level you sort of.... fall, smash, break, and get stuck into.  You are not mearly on a path, but crash into every level.  The story and phsyco babble is decent and good voice acting.  I recomend it to people who love horror and 3rd person games.

												The Aliens to Dead Space 1's Alien, this is a much more action-oriented shooter than the first game.  Unfortunately, it pays for this by loosing a lot of the scare factor that permeated the first game, and I think it's weaker for it.  I never felt as vulnerable or challenged as I did in the first.  However, I will say the guns are a lot beefier, the combat is tighter, it doesn't have the visual issues like the stuttering v-sync problem and the zero-g sections are a lot more fun.  And, I will say there is one section in this game that is the creepiest in the whole trilogy.  All in all, it's still a decent game worth picking up on sale, especially since it's as close to a decent Aliens game as you're going to get for awhile.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 13, 2012
												Dead Space 2 is a little bit of Resident Evil 4, a little bit of Half-Life 2, a little bit of Doom 3, a little bit of The Thing, a little bit of 2001: A Space Odyssey and a little bit of Left 4 Dead. It's a great game and a lot of fun to play, especially for its scripted sequences, like the ones involving zero gravity and flight, plus the areas in which you get to fight with the Stalkers, the velociraptor-like necromorphs. It has a very cinematic quality, although I wished its story and dialogues had been written better. This game has been made by people who love the horror and sci-fi genre, but it didn't receive the polish that it deserved. You will finish it in about 15 hours, maybe give it a second try in a harder mode, and then never play it again - also because it seems that nobody cares about its multiplayer. But for those 15 hours you're in for some great time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 16, 2013
												Some games give its sequel demanding expectations to meet, and Dead Space is certainly one of them.  In Dead Space 2, the gameplay feels much smoother and the controls are more responsive than in its prequel.  Isaac Clarke has an entire wardrobe of engineering suits now, each having unique bonuses and advantages in combat.  Old weapons are modified and the new weapons bring more excitement into combat.  Some of the new enemies will swarm you in a pack, some will charge at you, and some are just overwhelmingly massive, but all present a fun challenge.  What really amazes me is that Dead Space 2 still managed to maintain an incredible story.  You’ll truly despise some of the characters, but also pray that others survive the necromorph massacre.  The graphics are gorgeous and sometimes breathtaking when venturing in space around Saturn.  If you enjoyed Dead Space 1, then this is a no-brainer.Gameplay: 20/20 … FLAWLESS (One of my best gameplay experiences ever.  Zero-G has never been this much fun.)Story: 10/10 … PERFECT (I truly grew to detest the antagonist and fret over the lives of the protagonists.  This is usually just analyzed in film/literature, but the character development was particularly impressive.)Graphics: 5/5 … PERFECT (Disable V-Sync in-game and force it on from your GPU control panel.  D3D Overrider eliminates micro-stuttering if you’re as picky as I am.)Sound/Music: 5/5 … PERFECTControls: 0/0 … OMITTED (The mouse & keyboard is better than in Dead Space 1, but I still strongly recommend a controller.)Overall: 100% (40/40) … WOW!!!

Isaac's inner struggle in the tense setting of "Sprawl" provides an unforgettable atomsphere, making Dead Space 2 one of the most terrifying and unmissable horror games this generation and the benchmark for others to follow.

												An incredible game, unfortunately ruined by EA's "Free DLC" that breaks the pacing of the game by giving you all the most powerful weapons and armor at word go for free. Ruins the tension and difficulty for absolutely no reason. You can't turn it off, you just have to hunt for the legitimate parts through a menu full of high level equipment to find the stuff you actually have to pay for. Ruins the game.Find it on console and play it without connecting to the internet. That's the only way to play, which I still recommend that you do.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												7 out of 10 The first Dead Space was a fantastic game with great atmosphere, suspense, interesting story and nasty enemies.  The second installment does exactly the same thing for the first 90% of the game.  Then suddenly it tries to be something it was not designed for - be a fast paced action shooter.  This last bit irritated the daylights out of me. The good - First 90% percent of the game is a great follow up to the first Dead Space.  Atmosphere, suspense and intrigue. - Interesting action where head shots don't kill enemies. - The new enemie-types adds an interesting dimension. - Not a game I wanted to play late at night. The bad - I am no fan of the camera style - over-the-shoulder 3d-person.  At least I did not feel like it hindered the game. The ugly - The last 10% of the game is just irritating.  Trying too hard to be a fast-paced action title. - Over the top gruesome death scenes.
